Pequod's offers a bit of a twist on the traditional Chicago-Style pizza you would get at a Lou Malnati's or Giordano's.  Their "burnt" crust is something you'll either love or hate, but I am a fan, and most people I've eaten Pequod's with are as well.  Solid sauce and toppings, but I find the overall quality of the pizza to be a clear notch below Lou Malnati's and Pizano's in the fight for best in Chicago.

My brother raved about this place and took us here for some deep dish pizza while in town. And let me just say, it was amazing pizza!! The crust was thick and well done, but not overly done. And the toppings were a plenty. My SIL and I also shared the Pequod salad (a half order) and it was really good as well.Only downside is the service we had was terrible. The waitress never came back to check on us or refill our drinks throughout our entire meal. We got the deep dish pizza at least 15/20 mins before the thin crust, so our kids were starving...we had to even ask twice where the thin crust pizza was. We asked for a to-go box and the waitress brought us a completely flat (not put together) box and sort of tossed it on the table.Service aside, I would definitely go back if I am in town, because the pizza is really really good.

Amazing deep dish pizza! I have never been a huge fan of deep dish pizza so I was a bit hesitant to eat here! We came in around 7P.M on a Wednesday night and we were immediately seated on the second floor.We came as a group and ordered the full order of hot wings as an appetizer! They were loved at the table, spicy enough to satisfy you, but not enough to burn your mouth. I ordered a full order of a caesar salad and split it with my boyfriend. The salad was large enough for both of us and even had some extra to share with another person. However, the salad was very plain and only had 5 croutons on top of it! Another negative about the salad was that they give you the dressing on the side so you have to mix it! Do not get the salad, nothing special to it.We ordered two medium pan pizzas for the table. One was pepperoni and jalapeño, and the other pizza had meatball, Italian sausage and pepperoni (pictures attached). The pan pizzas were both big enough for a group of 5 people (2 children) and we even had to take some home! I highly recommend coming here!

Pizza was amazing!  We ordered the thin crust and deep dish.  They give you a generous amount of toppings on the pizza and unlimited toppings to choose from on their menu.   The restaurant is rather small so the wait was rather long..  we got there and they said that it would be a 45 minute wait and then another 60 minutes for the pizza to be prepared.  Get a small appetizer if you are hungry, but this pizza place is highly recommended !

Not only is the pizza one sloppy mess, but they show ZERO hospitality. We ordered a pizza to go, and within 5 minutes called to add wings and salad to our order. The woman on the phone said that they couldn't add anything, even salad, to our order after the pizza had gone in the oven! What? She was rude, short and irritable. We actually called 15 minutes later and placed another order with a different name to get around the system.  And on top of all this, they didn't even get my order right! Let me get an AMEN if you are done with this over rated, over priced, underwhelming sports bar. go cubs

Went here today with family (wife & 3 kids), after a artwalk & Lincoln Park revisit.  I've been seeing Pequod's, on YouTube & pizza review articles, as the best new reinvented Chicago style deep dish that beats out the old style by a mile!  Was planning on stopping here on our next family outing to Chicago and that's what we did.  After all the hype, was definitely  expecting this to be a winner for sure, but it was a big upset, like the Bears season opener against the Packers!Got there, they said it would be a 20 minute wait, waited 5 minutes and got seats, score!  Before we got seated, they said it would be 1 1/2 hour wait for pizza, understood as they were busy.  Got seated, server was quick with the drinks and refills.  Ordered 2 appetizers, they came blazing fast.  Server check-in was very impressive, definitely a seasoned pro.  And then the pizza came, under an hour for sure, very impressed with the speed... But this is where everything falls apart, pie looked fantastic when it landed on the table haven't seen anything like it before, saucey, cheesy, carmalizied edges, in your face ingredients, but what counts the most is the final follow through...The taste buds approval!...Which was a upset!  Crust, dry & thick, no flavor.  Sauce, no flavor, like tomato sauce from the can.  The carmalizied crust, nothing to cheer for, burnt cheese tastes better.  Overall, it's like eating a pizza on toasted Italian bread.Final thoughts...over hyped and nothing to cheer for.  I've been Chicago since age 7, and tasted it all, and this place should be at the bottom with nothing to cheer about....Just my opinion, there's a lot better spots out there that aren't hyped that you should check out before coming here...

This place has GREAT food! Stopped by on a Thursday evening about 630pm. The place wasn't packed and immediately got a table. They do have a sign at the hostess station saying pizza can take about 40 minutes, which we were ok with. In the meantime, ordered a couple of beers and wings. Buffalo wings are delicious! Just the right spiciness to savor the flavor and enjoy them. We ordered a medium thin crust and a personal deep dish. The thin crust is not very thin, almost had the "regular" hand tossed thickness to it, but very flavorful. If you're a fan of pepperoni the way we are, get extra of it. The top layer is nicely charred and crispy with tons of flavor. The deep dish crust is also nicely charred and crispy and gives the pizza that extra flavor to satisfy your taste buds. This place is known for their deep dish and I could see why...the mixture of that sauce with the cheese and pepperoni was superb! The only reason I'm give it 4 stars and not 5 is because I truly enjoy a thin crust, crispy pizza, and this was not like that. Nonetheless, everything was delicious and will definitely visit when I'm back in Chicago! Check it out!!

Yep. Yep.......Yep, Pequod's lives up to the hype. We waited a while for our seat and pizza, but that was to be expected. I love the collaboration with Whale Tail to drink through your wait time. Parking was pretty easy in the area and in the end the pizza was amazing. We split a small and it was too much for us. I will say I'm glad I ordered extra cheese! The cheese is amazing!

Worth the wait!! Get your spot in line, then go next door to Whale Tale while you wait (30-45min for us on a Saturday evening). The bar is owned by the same people, so even if you aren't finished with your beer before the table is ready, they'll radio over and hold your table. This pizza is a MUST when you're in Chicago. Authentic deep-dish. Not too much cheese or too much sauce, and the perfect amount of crunch in the crust. Pequod's salad was a great choice as well. Very friendly waitstaff. Four of us shared a pitcher, a salad, and a large pizza with more than enough food to go around. We creeped on a guy sitting at the next table over who had some pesto ravioli that looked pretty delicious as well!

What can I say? Pequads is one of a kind when it comes to pizza in Chicago. Not to say that the Lou Malnati's and Giordano's aren't amazing, because they truly are; but if you haven't made your way over to pequads yet you are seriously doing yourself a disservice. Brace yourself, they don't take reservations and because they're so amazing they almost always have a wait. They do however offer what they call priority seating. This means if you know you're planning to come, they'll take your party's name and size and you pretty much get to cut to the front of the wait line when you arrive. We did this last night when we were here for a party of 5, and despite having a crowd waiting at the door, we were seated immediately. They have a well stocked bar available (also great during your wait for a table) and solid appetizers. Obviously the token item here though is their pan pizza. The crust is out of this world. It's got a crisp, caramelization to it that IMHO almost single handedly makes this my favorite pizza in Chicago. Furthermore, their toppings are baller. My favorite is the sausage and giardiniera. Yes, it's got a bit of a kick to it, but I'm a wimp when it comes to spicy/hot foods and still can't get enough of this. I've heard their Canadian bacon topping is also out of this world. Do yourself a favor, get to pequads ASAP.

Went here for dinner with my friend after seeing a movie at Webster Place Theater. I had my name put on the priority seating list before the movie and afterwards it was only a five minute wait. The service was great, our waitress checked on us frequently. The food was excellent , we had an antipasto salad and a pan pizza. Just some of the best pizza in Chicago and I have plenty of experience in that category. I found legal free parking in the area, but that was at 4 pm. Had a great time, highly recommended.

A Chicago staple that completely rocks. Recently waited on a Sunday for an hour and didn't eat until 10 but Pequods is 100% worth the wait. Their little buzzers still work 2 doors down at the Whales Tale bar and across the street at Barnes and Noble if you need to kill time and don't wait to wait inside the restaurant. For how busy they were, the service was great, the pizza was delicious and we left fat & happy. Good beer list. Pro tip: extra sauce. Do it. Our bill was about 60 bucks between three people and we got the Caesar, beers and a large pan. Super reasonable!

Being newish to Chicago a few people had recommended Pequod's so I gave it a try.Overall the pizza was pretty damn delicious. A thicker yet airy dough, flavorful sauce, plenty of topping options and a very delicious crispy crust. I do however think there could have been more cheese. With deep dish/pan I just expected it to be cheesier. I appreciated the selection of appetizers and salads. Since the pizza takes about 45 minutes to cook it was nice to have something to eat while we were waiting for the main dish. And although I didn't get desert, it was also nice to see that a pizza place had so many options for sweets. Service was great. Our waitress was attentive and checked on us during the appropriate times. For a Tuesday night in early spring we waited about 20ish minutes to get a table around 6 o'clock. I'd say the earlier you can get there the better chance you have of not waiting in line for super long. And if at all possible try to avoid the tables by the door. Large groups can form while people wait for a table and it just feels awkward having people so close to you while eating. Even the waitress was annoyed as she was trying to work her way through the crowd to get to her patrons. And at one point people were literally leaning on the chairs at our table while we ate. I get it, it's cold outside but really do you have to be right on top of me as I eat dinner?
I'm from Chicago. Pizza matters. And this is my new "You must go here for pizza" when friends are visiting. Thank you for existing.

Really mediocre pizza IMO. Salad looked like it came from a bag. Really loud and staff was arguing with each other in hallway. It is pretty affordable which is really the only positive. Wouldn't recommend.

We perused yelp for the perfect place to try true Chicago style deep dish pizza and settled on Pequods as our choice. I'm so glad that we did because the pizza was as delicious as I'd expected to be and then some. The cheese creates a heavenly, caramelized, crunchy halo around the crust and the favor of the sauce is wonderfully deep. It was perfect. Definitely a must-try for those looking for their own deep dish experience!

Coming to Chicago, my main mission was to try deep dish pizza. After asking recommendations from many locals for places to try, I decided to come here.I came during lunch and it was pretty busy but we didn't have to wait. I got the lunch special which is a personal size pan cheese pizza with a soft drink. I decided to add spinach on half of the pizza to try.It did take a while for our pizza to come but they do everything fresh to order and there was a large group ahead of us so I didn't mind as much.My first bite into the pizza was amazing. I love the crunch of every bite I took as well as the balance between sauce, cheese and dough. It wasn't too cheesy, or sauce, or doughy, it was perfect ratio. I dont know how they keep the outside part of the pizza to be crunchy but the inside was still soft and doughy but it was good. The only critique I had was that there was literally only 4 pieces of spinach on my half side and had to pay extra for it.Overall, it was a good pizza and I can see this as my go to pizza if we have this in Washington.

O...M...G....The best pizza, period.  The crust, wow.  What other deep dish pizza can you think of where you can pick up the slice and eat it with your hands without it going everywhere?  Crispy bottom with carmelized cheese around the crust that makes it amazing.  Service is good, not great, but the food makes up for it.

Delicious pizza! The restaurant is bigger inside than it seems since there is an entire upper level with seating. Pizza does take about 40 minutes but they let you know that up front. The sides look like it's black and burnt but it's really crisp and delicious and does not at all taste burnt. Pizza is a bit on the pricey side with toppings being about $2.50 more a piece. I do wish the pizza had a little more cheese to it, so next time I may order it with extra cheese. All in all it was delicious and we will definitely be back.

The best pizza in the effing world. I live in New York and I've traveled through Italy. I've eaten a lot of pizzas in a lot of styles. Nothing can top this pie. I had this pizza for the first time at the Morton Grove location well before the Food Network makes it one of the top five pizzas. Now when I visit Chicago, I come to this location because it's way more convenient and the pizza is the same. The wait is always insane but it's worth it. This visit, I came at 4:30 to beat the rush. I was seated immediately but told that my pizza would take 45 minutes from the time I ordered. This was good - I've waited over two hours just to get a table before. I'm not adding anything new by gushing over the caramelized cheesy crust. It's well established that that crust is what sets it apart. The dough to topping ratio is also on point, and the sauce has the tiniest hint of spice which makes all of the flavors sing. I'm not exaggerating when I say I've dreamed of this pizza.

Any time we make a trip downtown we have to stop here even if it's just to pick up a pizza to go. Love the pizza, the burnt cheese crust and the piles of pepperoni that is on it! It's pretty much always busy but there's a reason for that...it's delicious!

Delivery/take-out review - I've never eaten in, the wait is always atrocious.Overall: Great pizza, but it can be hit or miss in terms of the waiting periods for whether or not its worth it.The good: When it's good, it's REALLY good. Hot and fresh, its on top with the best of Chicago. The carmelzied crust is signature goodness, and the thin crust is really good too. They pile the toppings on high, the sauce ratio is plentiful, and the meat is always loaded. The crust is thick and crunchy.The not-so-good: On one occasion, the super bowl, the order was terribly late and incorrect. Not sure whether to blame doordash or Pequods. Also, if the pizza is late and cold, it's not nearly as divine.

Delicious. Awesome that you can order ahead and just sit down & eat. Good service. The air conditioner was unfortunate & it was hot but that's no ones fault just a hot day. Bridgette S. was very friendly & prompt in her service!
Nope, I'm not going to share that this is my favorite as you'll only make the line longer! Best in town!

Whenever we mentioned to our Lyft/Uber drivers that we had a dinner date at Pequod's Pizzeria, they all reacted with high fives and verbal approvals like "HAIL YEAH" or "Nice nice nice." This grew our hype for Pequods, and it did NOT disappoint!Note about their reservation system: It does not mean you get seated immediately. You still need to wait a bit (kind of like a FastPass system at Disneyland). Luckily, there are some cool bars around the immediate area. My wife and I ended up going to Kibbitznest across the street for a warm drink. Pequods buzzed us about 30 minutes later.The pizza is amazing! Since it takes awhile for the pizza to be ready (they were insanely packed), we ordered some chicken wings as appetizers. They were delicious. Our pizza came out about 20 minutes later, and wow. My mouth is watering just thinking about that beautiful pie. They do not mess around with toppings (we got 5, and our pizza was overflowing). The crust is cooked to perfection: Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. It was a glorious meal and I wish there was a Pequod's Pizzeria everywhere.Service was great, location is a bit away from downtown Chicago, and ambiance is cool. My suggestion for any first timers is to not get so many toppings on one pizza. Like I said: They do not skimp on the toppings. Two toppings would be more than enough, maybe three. But five was definitely too much and I ended up scraping off half of my toppings per slice. This is definitely a must visit for any pizza lover!

Being a huge fan of deep dish pizza, I was genuinely let down by the mainstream (and admittedly touristy) spots like Lou Malnati's and to a lesser extent, Giordano's. I was taken there by a friend native to Chicago against my will and I was craving something more unique afterwards. That's when I went to Pequod's Pizza. You walk inside Pequod's and you aren't greeted with the best customer service (still, the staff is pleasant) or the best atmosphere around; but you're greeted with absolutely amazing food. That's why you come here-- for the pizza. Pequod's does things a bit differently. The crust of the pizza is carmelized and has a fantastic crunch to the initial bite. The ingredients from the cheese to the meats and veggies all taste and look fresh. As with any deep-dish spot, there is the dreaded ~40 minute wait for your pizza to cook. However, Pequod's throws you a bone and offers you a free coffee, hot chocolate, or soda at the Whale Tale just steps away from the restaurant. Still, I recommend sharing a few appetizers and crisp beers to help make the wait easier.What I tried & liked:Small Deep-Dish Pizza: I topped my pizza with chicken and jalapenos and couldn't be happier. Naturally, deep-dish is extremely heavy and it's tough to get past a couple of slices (a good problem to have). But never would I imagine that the carmelized crust makes this pizza SO much better than the competition. Baking the pies in the seasoned cast-iron pans with cheese really adds a second element to the pizza missing from major chains.Things I tried & disliked:Cheesy Garlic Bread - It's your run-of-the-mill garlic bread topped with cheese. It wasn't particularly delicious and felt more like garlic bread I should receive at a dive bar. I'd recommend trying another appetizer like mozzarella sticks or onion rings-- those are difficult to get wrong.Pequod's is not in downtown-- in fact, it can be inconvenient to get here and have to head all the way back to the city. But there's a good reason why Pequod's has such a strong following, even more than that of its mainstream rivals. For what the restaurant lacks in overall polish, it more than makes up for with its unique pizza. Don't leave Chicago without trying it!

This pizza was just ok. Crust was good but the sauce didn't taste fresh at all :(Prefer Lou Malnati's to this any day. Also the location lacks ambiance... it's very dark and there is no natural light. Would not return here.

The pizza is worth waiting for. We made a 'priority table' request (which you have to do at least 24 hours ahead of time) as a party of 2 on a Monday night, and waited less than 20 minutes from check in. The pizza did take a while to come- about 50 Mins from when we ordered, so it's worth ordering an app. We got the fried mushrooms- they were decent and staved off the hunger until our pepperoni, mushroom, olive and basil (the fresh basil is KEY) deep dish arrived. Great pizza, and I'd wait again for it. Taking off 1 Star because 1) we were seated right next to a garbage can- like if I bent my elbow out, it would have hit the overflowing garbage can. YUCK. I get it, it's a busy place- but if there isn't space for a table, don't stick it there. And 2) the place is pretty dirty- floors needed sweeping, the table was sticky, and the booths next to our table looks pretty grimy too. Also soda water out of the tap was $2.75- for a bottle of San Pellegrino maybe, but that was one charge that surprised me, in an otherwise fairly-priced place.

So I HATE deep dish pizza but decided to give Pequods a try since I was with a large group! It was the most amazing, most delicious pizza in the world. I would totally go back to Chicago to have this pizza!Five stars from me!!

It's 5'oclock somewhere. Ugh I LOVE their margarita pizza. Always crispy and yummy. Not much more to say! Quick deliveries, and always looks good when I open the box and lay my eyes on that cheesy beauty!

A lot of hype for this place. We ordered pizza for pick up - it was ready as promised in 45 minutes. It does look like a nice place to dine in with two floors. For the pan pizza with pepperoni - 5 stars. It reminded me of when I ate with my family as a child at a Pizza Hut overseas. At the time it felt like a 5-Star pizza restaurant. Crispy caramelized crust delivers! For the thin crust cheese pizza we ordered - 2 stars. The topping sloughed off like it was a poorly homemade pizza with the premade crust.
Chicago pizza is Pequod's.  Skip the deep dish, go for the fire pan baked garlic cheesy burnt crust. You might not be able to handle it.

Some serious Chicago pie! Pequod's contends with best deep dish in the city and has never disappointed. The place is always packed and you will always wait 15-45 minutes, if not at the bar then standing outside. The website even says "Priority Seating requests can be made online, by email or phone. Priority Seating Requests are NOT GUARANTEED RESERVATIONS." So, either visit during off hours or be prepared to wait. The two-floor restaurant has a divey feel--nothing fancy about silverware or place setting-- but the food is no joke. There's not a bad pizza on the menu, but I'm partial to the pan pepperoni. The apps are just as tasty, but you'll need to save room if you want more than 1-2 slices! I love Pequod's for its quintessential Chicago-ness: sports paraphernalia, a game on tv, and some hearty 'za.

Pequod's is my favorite, but it is definitely an acquired taste. If you're visiting Chicago, I'd definitely recommend trying Pequods and Lou Malnatis to get a few different styles of deep dish. Pequod's is a great neighborhood restaurant that's normally very busy, so expect to wait. It's worth it, and you won't find this style elsewhere.

I'm so disappointed! I use to LOVE this place. I came here a few weeks back and asked for a table for three, including my toddler. I wanted a booth and was rudely told no because I could not put a high chair on the edge of the booth, which I understood. I told the hostess that I would go without the high chair. I just wanted to sit in a booth rather a table. The tables are located in the middle of the restaurant where you get hit with everyone's coats as they pass by. She said something under here breath, walked us to our table and literally threw the menus on the table. As she walked away, she called me a b*tch in spanish, probably not knowing I spoke spanish. Usually if I'm unhappy with the service I just won't go back but I was so mad I just had to speak with the manager. When the manager came to our table, he was laughing and distracted by other employees. He seemed very young and uninterested in what I was saying to him. I don't expect great service from a pizza joint but the plain disrespect is uncalled for. I love the pizza here but I will never return and I'll make sure to spread the word.
Great People. Good tasty pie. Crust is great. My family devoured the pizza. Sauce was traditional. Topping reminded me of homemade pizza. Pizza by slice or whole pie.

Unfortunately, as a potential new customer there, we spoke w "Katie" who I will add,  initially said she was the "delivery coordinator " and she was simply rude and couldn't answer a simple question about delivery logistics without fully listening and before cutting me off ; "I just asked you for what time?!" Pardon?! and then "accidentally" disconnected call . When I called back I explained to call taker we were just trying to gage if maybe best if we should pick up rather than waiting over an hour?!  And I explained I wanted to speak to the manager Bc of the lack of customer service and how abrupt/rude Ms. Katie is. And what do you know folks "Katie" gets on phone and is now the Manager too! LOL! Cmon. Make up your mind. Certainly could recognize the voice immediately. Either way, hence the "first time customer" simply asking questions.

Originally when I heard about this place, it felt like people were pulling my leg.   "Pequods" sounded like someone was luring you into a dark alley of a bad joke.  I've had my fair share of deep dish experiences around Chicago, but this one is definitely my favorite.  Maybe because it's not as "commercialized" as some of the cough, cough.... other competitors, but it has a great local, lived-in feel.The other thing I liked about it is that it was a little difficult to get to.... why is this a point I like to share?  It just feels like a little "off the beaten path" so that it's really not intended to be a tourist trap.  It is a good 15-18min walk from the Belmont (Red/Brown/Purple Lines) CTA stop, but there is also street parking available.  I suggest the walk... since it will prepare you for the carb-loading heaving you are about to experience when you come here.We arrived early.... party of 4 with a high-chair and we got seated right away (even though there was just 2 of us of the party present).  I like that it's first-come-first-serve so that people that eat early to avoid crowds are rewarded and there's no really extensive reservation process.  We were escorted past a bar (all seats filled) of people enjoying food and beverages and a bunch of high-top tables.  We were lucky enough to get a booth and the high-chair fit perfectly on the end of the table.  You can tell the server was busy with a party of 12/mix of kids and adults that basically "sheilded us" off from the other part of the restaurant since they extended the booth table with long tables to accommodate the large party, but our server kept checking on us.  We put in an appetizer that arrived as the rest of our party did and we placed our pizza order right away.  Half topping large between 4 people after a sample platter of appetizers was just enough food. My only complaint is that the server that brought the pizza served us the slices so the photo op for the pizza was gone is a second.  I did what I could though.  We passed the time with beer and good company and just taking the atmosphere in.  By the time we left, the entire restaurant was full as were our stomachs.  I'd be interested to come back and try their thin crust... which a lot of tables were enjoying around us.

Best deep dish in Chicago (or so our Chicago friends say)!! This place was absolutely delicious--the crust is perfectly caramelized, the staff is super nice and helpful, and the pizza itself was super yummy. I've heard people make a trip to Chicago just for the deep dish and I'd for sure come back for Pequods.
...it's Pequod's. It's literally the best pizza. You don't need anymore of an explanation than that. Go. Eat.

Love this place. Has great deep dish at a really good price. Met up with a friend from the app Bumble! We had a great time and I'm so glad that me and my new friend have a go-to spot now! I highly recommend coming here, and trying out the app as well! Especially if you want to find someone new to come eat here with.
The best pizza in Chicago, hands down.  It's always busy and the service is always slow, but it's worth it.  The pizza does have a lot of sauce, so ask for light sauce or extra-cooked.

Oh Chicago pizza, I have heard so much about you. When an entire city is known for pizza, not just one restaurant, which one am I supposed to choose?! It's a tough decision possibly made easier by the fact that you can't go wrong.Pequod's was not what I expected at all. It was like a pub/bar feel, with small tables all over the place and just a couple of booths on the side. The menu is pretty much just pizza and a few other selections like pasta and salad. Their pizzas come in thin crust or pan pizza, and come in 10", 12", 16"(14" for pan). The pan pizza also offers a personal 7" size. Each topping is 50 cents and you can add as many as you want.The two of us ordered a small (10") pan pizza to share and it was about the right size. We probably could have done a medium, but we would be really stuffed. Never having this deep dish of a pizza before, I wasn't expecting to be so full, but there's just so much crust and cheese that it fills you up pretty quickly.Now apparently this isn't really the deepest of deep dish, but it's still pretty deep compared to other pizzas. The crust is so crispy in the bottom and the sides of the crust have this layer of burnt cheese all the way up the sides that is just so good. The sauce and cheese are in just the right amounts to not be too saucy/cheesy, and the sausage that we got as a topping was amazing -- perfectly cooked and spiced and great with the sauce and cheese.I don't eat pizza much in general, but was really excited to try some Chicago pizza on my trip. Pequod's did not disappoint at all, and only makes me want to find some good deep dish back at home. The service is as fast as it can be (it takes close to 45 minutes ro make a pizza), and the atmosphere is fun and lively, with TV's and drinks to go around. Whether you're out of state like me or a Chicago native, definitely stop by this place and see what the hype is about!!

I've had mostly good experiences here. They're not located downtown, so they get lost in the Chicago saturation of Giordano's and Lou's and aren't famous with or necessarily sought out by tourists, which is honestly great. That being said, they are still busy AF, but there's definitely a sweet spot in terms of arrival time. I've brought Brits, Icelanders, and Russians here and all of them had their minds blown. The Russian tried to order a salad, but we threatened him with harm and he came around. Anyways, the food. The pizza is amazing. I'm not sure from where they source their sauce, but it's deliciously tomato-ey with the perfect amount of acidity and seasoning that stands out we'll all against the rafts of cheese and toppings. The crust is what everyone talks about though, so on to that. It's more pillowy than Giordano's, which is good in its own right. G's is a crisper, more buttery crust and is LOADED with toppings. P's definitely privileges the crust experience as they sprinkle it with cheese on the outside which forms a crunchy, crusty exterior. The crust-to-toppings-and-sauce at P's definitely favors the much thicker crust, so if you're into bread this is your pizza. I had a slightly negative experience when I had family come visit recently, but it was largely rectified. We had two small children with us, so I called them, understanding their reservation policy is really just sort of a 1/2 line-skipper policy and asked when to come in. We were told 5:00 was good so we did that. We showed up on time and proceeded to wait our 30 minutes we were told about. Came and went, waited 10 additional minutes. Went and talked to hostess and she said they were getting our table ready. 10 more minutes went by (50 minutes total for us public school kids) and I'm nine months pregnant with two insane 3 year olds so I saunter up there looking fat and hungry and am told just a few more minutes. I tell my family I'm pretty pissed since we came when we were told to come and we're still waiting at an hour; they still want to wait it out. I speak to a manager. Apparently the long wait was because the hostess seated another party that just waltzed in unannounced at our table and there wasn't another one available for a bit but he would "take care" of us. We were eventually seated around the 1.25 hour mark. The manager took our order while we were waiting and our pizza showed up shortly after we sat down. We got comped a pitcher of 3 Floyds, which was really nice, so all in all it evened out in the end in terms of pizza arrival time vs. wait time! They definitely screwed up, but owned up to it and fixed it as best as they could. Good job Pequods.

3 hour waits on the weekends during prime time but duhh it's because it's the best pizza EVER!  The carmelized crust is just everything. I feel like I just put up with eating the pizza portion just to get to the crust.  Pro tip: If you get pepperoni, dont get it with any other toppings because other toppings will make it watery.   I've tried it with mushrooms, onions, sausage..just plain pepperoni is the best!

It was my family's first time in Chicago and this was a spot on our list of deep dishes to try! We got the plan deep dish, supreme deep dish, and fried peppers. I think we were expecting deep, deep dish with lots of cheese. However, this was a LOT of bread. Also, there was no A/c on the lower level and we went during the heat wave in July. So we were sweating and eating - not a good combo!

This is our first trip to Chicago so deep-dish pizza is obviously a must-try. We found this place by doing a quick Google search of "best pizza in Chicago" then clicking one of the first search results.Allow me to preface the rest of the review by acknowledging that we came on a Saturday night, presumably the busiest night for this restaurant (or any restaurant, to be honest). Maybe some of the things we saw are not the norm. But I'm still going to rate based on our experience.Before going we requested priority seating on their website but I'm not sure it actually made a difference. When we arrived the estimated waiting time was an hour but when we gave our priority seating request the hostess said the wait would be 20-30 minutes, which is what the website said. Cut to ~50 minutes later & we're finally going inside. Everyone before us (about 20-25 people) has already gone inside as well, defeating the purpose of a priority seating request. While the website does say that a request for priority seating is not a reservation, the fact that the hostess told us "20-30 minutes" was a little annoying.Once we finally get upstairs we're placed at a small table near the stairwell. Great seating, not a problem. The only issue is that when I sit down I scrape my fingernail on the table (as occasionally happens with long nails) & felt something come up. I looked down and yep, that's food residue. Wonderful. Looking around at the floor reveals much of the same. There's food on the ground & a lot of it. By this point we're starving & as long as the plates come out clean, no one is really going to complain much. And they did come out clean. After being told the pizza wouldn't be ready for another hour we ordered cheesy garlic bread. Really good, especially with the pizza sauce that came out with it. As for the actual pizza, I got the small pepperoni pan with extra cheese & fresh garlic. Look, I'm already an "eat everything with a knife and fork" kind of girl, but this pizza really called for a knife and a fork. And a bib. It was so good I was a tiny bit afraid I would pass out in it. They also make their sauces in house which is really cool. I had the ranch which was delicious, as was the pizza sauce that came with the cheesy garlic bread. I got two little containers to go -- one for the rest of the pizza & one for whatever else I needed to put ranch on. Honestly the food was so good I didn't mind the wait.I gave this place 3 stars for the amazing food & took off two for the sheer amount of food that was everywhere. It is possible that we were seated in a particularly bad spot but a couple that came in about an hour after us were seated then 5 minutes later got out of their booth for a waitress to sweep under their table. There was just too much food where there shouldn't have been. Next time we'll swing by on a week night.

All I heard about was Chicago deep dish pizza. Like how its a must when in town. Well I was in town and lucky for me I just happened to cruise by here. It must be an aquired taste. Im used to Socal pizza in all its styles. Yes I'll rate above and beyond anything Round Table has to offer but I just can't give it 5 star treatment. Service was great and food came out on time piping hot. The sauce and topping were all on point. Its just the crust...was a lil bland. Sorry guys

Holy macaroni....before I begin, let me just state that I don't like cheese. The only time I tolerate cheese, maybe even enjoy it a little is when it's a light amount on a hot out of the oven pizza. I never in a million years thought I would ever crave, let alone LIKE a deep dish pizza because of the amount of cheese. I now stand corrected. My favorite pizzas are Round Table in Redding, CA, Regina's in North End Boston and Juliana's in Brooklyn. But now "PeePots" is my new number 1. PERFECT crust with lacy edges, AMAZING sauce they should jar and sell, DELICIOUS stringy chewy cheese to hold it all together, spicy thin pepperoni with burnt edges....my mouth is watering and I just ate it 8 hours ago. I just might have to stop by again before we leave Chicago....1,000% worth the wait!

I've been a pizza fanatic my entire life and, WOW, this is the best pizza I have ever eaten! (no joke!)...  I will most definitely be back here next time I am in Chicago.  I love that they are open late, it's easy to park, the food here is delicious and reasonably priced. The environment is cool and laid-back...  What isn't to love??  This is officially my new favorite pizza place in the world! :)
Good pizza, the caramelized crust is very tasty. Tho the toppings are very expensive. Especially when they don't have options that includes toppings like any other pizza place.
Love the unique take on Chicago Style. Long wait but worth it!

This is where we were advised to go for Chicago deep dish. We went around 3pm in pouring rain (in November 2017) so there was no line. The pizza was good, but I think the sauce was a bit off for me. Maybe too sweet? The service is good there, but I think I'd try another deep dish place the next time.Then again, I prefer NYC-style Sicilian pizza over this Chicago deep dish pan pizza. And overall, my favorite is still NYC's thin crust pizza...

Open late- wait was as expected for a deep pan pizza. We love Chicago-style but hadn't had it quite like this, the dough was crunchy! Which can be a good thing but this was a bit much- at least an inch of it made it a bit too dry. The caramelized edges were the best part! Service was good, but the whole place has a dive-bar vibe.

Not quite traditional Chicago deep dish, but Pequods never fails to deliver. If you are willing to wait for a table or extra long delivery times, it will def be worth every bite once you sink your teeth into the crunchy crust!

Its like they say Best Pizza In Chi-LandWould say its Deep Dish is very different from the rest! Love the caramelized crust. Thinking of it it's making me hungry a little right now!Got some salad while waiting and would say we the pizza did not take too long.Definitely got lucky with seating would recommend making a reservation. We didn't but it was pack after we came in.

Take it from a New Yorker who's never really enjoyed deep dish, this place deep dish was the best thing I've ever had! Went into Pequod's on a friends tip and trusted the instinct to go here. I went in on a Thursday around 2PM and there no wait for 4 which was great, pizza wait was about 20 minutes which is the usual wait and when It did come It was amazing!! The cheese cause ratio was just right! The sauce was super flavorful and the cheese was great cheesy goodness. The crust was perfectly baked and a bit crunch around the edges which made the pit even better. If you have sometime and want to enjoy some great deep dish definitely stop by!

Still dreaming about this pizza. We got a large sausage pan pie and it was amazing - they definitely have the best crust! The staff was super friendly and the music was A+. The pizza does take about 45 minutes to cook so we got some garlic bread and onion rings as apps, which were pretty standard.

As good as the others have said.  I'm a big fan of Chicago pizza and was only in town for one evening with the family.  We had a couple of Chicago newbs with us, so I really wanted to show off the pie.  Never had Pequod's before, and I lean towards Giordano's.  But it was a holiday weekend and I didn't want to tempt the crowds, so this place was close and we gave it a try.Even ordering carry out was a challenge.  The place was packed!  Took 10 minutes to get through the door to the bar to place an order.  Found a couple leaving their bar stools, so we were able to sit and enjoy a couple of craft brews while the pizza took its 60 minute journey through the kitchen.  When we got the pies home, they were just outstanding.  Had an all meat one and an all veggie one.  Both had ample toppings, plenty of cheese, and a very tasty red sauce.  I would come back again in a heart beat.

I'm hesitant to give this place 3 stars given its huge reputation. I was told this competes with the top pizza places in Chicago. It was OK, just your average deep dish pizza but a bit burnt around the crust (caramelized as they call it), it also smells great! The service was phenomenal, though. The waiters make sure you're not left alone for a long time. The place itself almost has ZERO oxygen, it was very stuffy and as if the air was sucked out of it! :/ at one point I felt like I was suffocating due to lack of air/proper circulation in the place. So I really recommend choosing a spot near the open windows.

My friend and I are visiting the city and were recommended to come to Pequod's for the deep dish experience. When we gave our name for the wait, we were told 10 minutes plus the additional 40 minutes that will be needed to cook the pizza. OK... We waited an hour and 20 minutes to be seated and then the 40 minutes for our pizza! A few times we nicely asked the front counter what was our wait time that remained and why there were so many open seats in the restaurant. We were met with impatience towards our comments and rude remarks back. He explained people can reserve a table and they must hold it for up to two hours... Very inefficient operations if this is true!We were seated upstairs, (to our surprise this area existed) where there was more empty seats. However, our waitress was extremely nice! She fully sympathized with us and was prompt in taking our order and making sure we had everything we needed throughout our meal. We had onion rings to hold us over (they were alright) and got a plain deep dish pizza. The pizza itself was very good! The crust was perfectly crunchy and the sauce was sweet and delicious. Pequod's does have great deep dish, but their restaurant operations and parts of their customer service/interactions need to be improved.

I come from New York and new haven pizza so I was excited to experience the deep dish life. I swear this was a notch down from school cafeteria pizza. The sauce tasted like ketchup. The crust was just doughy and had zero flavor. It felt like a pizza you make using Pillsbury crust and the lowest grade cheese. Super disappointed

It had been so many years since I was at this location and, wow, what a change in crowd! I mean, still a young crowd but we got older, but it was never nearly as packed back in the day as it was this week. What a crowd! We called ahead and got priority on the seating list and that made a big difference, but we were fortunate enough to immediately get two seats at the bar and get served quickly and place our order quickly with a great bartender.Our salad and appetizer came super quickly which made the wait for our ever delicious Pequod's Pizza a little easier. I didn't want an iceberg and romaine mix and the bartender was happy to have spinach swapped out for my side salad order. Very accommodating.Our classic, deep dish Pequod's pie came within about 30 to 45 minutes, piping hot. Delicious as always! Caramelized rim of the crust and top as always!I'm so used to going to the Morton Grove location, which I love, yet I was not disappointed in coming to the Clybourn location!

We really enjoyed Pequod's - I think it's the best deep dish that I've had in Chicago.Of course they have the ridiculous caramelized crust.... which is one of the main attractions. The sauce is very fresh and great, a touch too sweet - cheese is perfect. The start of the show -  the toppings are on point - pepperoni, onion and giardiniera is the way to go. I'm salivating  all over the keyboard. Great beer selection at a reasonable price.

Pequods...be still my heart. Your deep dish sausage and pepperoni pizza is what pizza dreams are made of. Your crust perfectly crunchy on the bottom yet soft and so light. Your sauce deliciously zesty and full of flavor. Your cheese nicely crisped on the edges and melted perfectly on top. And your sausage and pepperoni (and I typically don't like pepperoni)...goodness it's all too tasty. I've had the other Chicago deep dishes and they've got nothing on you. Not their crusts, not their sauces, and not their toppings. I shall dream of you til we meet again.

If you can make it over here, GET YOUR DEEP DISH HERE!I've been here twice now, and I have really enjoyed it each time.The atmosphere is relaxed, and very sports-bar-like, with TVs dotted around space. They have a second floor with more seating, but as a whole, the place does not have the most seating. I've heard of people have to wait for hours on weekends.I've only been here on weekdays for dinner, and I have never had to wait.I've come with a larger group, and we do call ahead.As for food, two large pizzas is perfect for eight people. And don't forget to add a couple beers! Alogether, two large pizzas and two pitchers of beer ended up being 16.44. Great value for money!And honestly, best deep dish. The cheese to crust to topping ratio is very even. The crust is cook slightly over so that it is cheesy and crisp on the outside. So. GOOD!And the waiters have always been very helpful in helping us decide what to order, and are very attentive to our drinks situation.If you are going to get deep dish, come here!

Pizza was amazing!! highly recommend!!  appetizers were just average. we got there and they told us we would have to wait an hour and a half for a table, only waited 50 minutes, but it was strange when we went to the hostess initially, she told us to come back in 45 minutes for a pager since they had run out. get more pagers maybe??? i'm sure this is not the first time that happened. i feel like if i wouldn't have gone up to get the pager sooner we would've missed out on our table if we weren't standing inside waiting, while most people did stand out in the cold. they took 3 groups of us upstairs & seated a couple that came AFTER us, before us, incredibly annoying. our waitress was just ok, she a different tables appetizers down on our table then once she realized she picked them up and placed them on their table and it took her 25 minutes after our pizza came to come to us and ask if everything was okay. i would carry out instead of dine in, next time.
The best pizza, it's always full, wait is long but worth it! Good vibes, good service.

One of my first Chicago deep dish experiences. Saw this place on the Food Network. It was pretty good. Not quite mind blowing like they showed on TV. Really crowded. Looking forward to trying a couple of other places
I was a decent pizza place. Nothing to really brag about especially since we are in Chicago.

I was suggested by many for a true Chicagoan pizza experience and was not disappointed. I suggest going on a week day, I went on a week day morning and a wait time was nonexistent, however you will wait 30-40 min for your pizza regardless because it takes time for the dough to finish cooking. Onwards to the pizza! The sauce was evenly spread, plentiful, and danced with the spices and herbs while the cheese melted in the gooey, savory masterpiece harmonizing with the scrumptious toppings instead of simply laying on top. I was impressed, and although I am not a fan of the deep dish, I know pizza lovers will continue to flock and fraternize. I highly recommend the garlic bread, I can't begin to describe how heavenly it was.

I have NEVER in my life had such terrible service... I called at 6:30 to order food. I was told 1 hour 15 minutes for wait time. Not bad for a Saturday night?? I arrive at 7:45 to pickup my pizza and they tell me it's almost ready. LOL I just got my pizza at 9:10pm. They make you pay as soon as you arrive and then they never give you time updates. When they handed me my pizza, I let her know my wings were missing.. she told me sorry you didn't pay for wings. So I asked her to print my receipt and guess what was on there? WINGS.  She threw my receipt at me and 15 minutes later brought out the rest of my food. I'm sure the food is great, haven't had a chance to eat it but the staff and and organization is so terrible that I will never eat there again. PLEASE DONT WASTE YOUR TIME! Worst experience yet in Chicago.

Don't bother reserving "priority seating" because it doesn't make a difference. Two groups of 8 show up 30 seconds apart. One called ahead. Can you guess who got sat first???Update: Took 40 minutes to be sat with "priority seating." Pitcher of beer we were given was not what we asked for. Had to ask several times to get get plates for the group we had. Had to ask several times to get forks for the table. Asked for half pepperoni half cheese and was given whole cheese. But they said a medium cheese pizza was being made to fix the mistake, which took an additional 25 minutes to get to us. I've never been so disappointed with a restaurant before. Failure on all accounts; host, server, bartender, cooks, they literally all failed on our table. I'm sad about it cuz I love the pizza but the service was so bad I may not return.

This place is hands down the best deep dish pizza in the city in my opinion.  Who doesn't love a cripsy cheese crust?It gets really busy on game nights.  If you go on a Friday make sure you go early.  The best time to visit without a wait is to come during the weekday or during the day on a Saturday or Sunday.

Oh my gosh Thick and good I'm outside of Atlanta currently living Therefore challenged in the quality pizza areaThe large will keep 2 ppl fed for 2 days.Loud and exciting Great locationGlad we walked 2 miles home after consuming Had to wait an hour for the pizza yet worth it.

Must try deep dish pizza! The dough is super soft with a caramelized crust. I haven't been to many places but it was well worth the wait. The appetizer combos and wings were just as good. We got two mediums which was more than enough for 6 people.

Pretty terrible all around. There are so many great deep dish pizza restaurants in Chicago, it's a waste of money and time to eat here. Dirty restaurant,  duck taped booths, dirty tables. Nothing charming about this place. The TVs all had news with rape and murder broadcasting across the screens so we had to ask our 10 year old to not look at all the glaring TVs. Waitress was slightly nice, but sick with a cold. Salad was brown and wilty with terrible ranch. Worst fried zucchini I've ever tasted. Terrible beer and wine list. Pizza is way too bready with the old Italian seasoning thrown in. Not enough cheese and sauce like traditional Chicago deep dish. Out of the way location. Please don't waste your money here.

Our family has gone to and ordered from Pequod's for years and years and years, long before the popularity has surfaced. I don't understand the attraction?  The pizza is good, the salads are eh, and the service is totally unpredictable.  Perhaps their growth in girth, fan appeal and space has created inconsistency in order accuracy, quality, and staffing.   There are better these days, in my opinion and NOT worth the long lines.

Pequod's is the best deep dish there is in Chicago. I can't count the number of high fives I got when I mentioned it as my favorite deep dish to foodie insiders. I took my boyfriend there this past weekend, he never had the sweet goodness of Chicago deep dish. The look of sheer joy and satisfaction on his face after taking a few bites said it all. The atmosphere was quiet on a Monday afternoon. The service was attentive, our server kept refilling our beverages and would check on us every so often. We were also impressed when she suggested we saved the ranch from our wings to dip our pizza, that is the type of thinking we appreciate. We had deep dish pizza with pepperoni and fresh garlic, we ordered buffalo wings before the pizza, there was a 20 minute wait for pizza, and we were starving. Be prepared on busier days the wait is longer 40 minutes or so. The pizza is phenomenal, the crust is crispy and buttery, the cheese, sauce and dough form a gooey paradise in your mouth. We left beyond full and headed to the airport and did not regret one bit of it.

Visiting from California.Nothing about this place was good. The pizza was the worst pizza I've ever had and that's saying a lot especially since this place was supposed to be Chicago's best pizzeria. I ordered a certain style of pizza, I received the completely opposite. I don't eat meat and the pizza came loaded with pepperoni, I guess for some that a good problem, yet for me it wasn't. The flavor was bland, the sauce didn't have enough spices and the cheese wasn't melted enough. I wouldn't eat here again, nor recommend anyone coming from out of town to eat here if they want good pizza.

The pizza was great, but the wait time was not. As to be expected with deep dish, the pizza took about 45 minutes. But when you take into account the amount of time it takes to be seated, etc. plan for at least an hour and a half before you will eat. Don't go starving. Also, do not go with a large group. We went with a group of 9 and were squeezed into a table that should fit 5-6. All in all, the food was wonderful, but the location is tiny.

One of the best pizza places to eat in chicago. The crust is a good amount of crispy and tastes really good (even though it looks burnt its not). It is a long wait to eat there but its definitely worth the wait!!
This place is amazing! My kids love it and I do too! We always order the pan pizza with extra caramelization sauce, sausage and pepperoni. WE LOVE IT!

Got here at 8pm on Wednesday night and there wasn't a wait. We ordered some fries and the single for 2 and it was more than enough of food. Be aware that it does take 30-40 minutes for the pizza to come. I was really hungry, so the fries were perfect to hold me over.Pizza- it was pretty good, as we ordered pepperoni and sausage for our toppings. It's greasier and messier than Lou malnatis, and they burnt the edges of the crust for a crispier flavor (not sure if that was intentional or not). We split the small 10" between 2 people and it's more than enough food. Don't order more than that or you're going to end up with a ton of leftoversService was good and it has more of a local atmosphere (compared to Lou's where it just felt like a touristy restaurant). Liked the bar ambiance and being able to watch the bulls and cubs games. Great value. Paid less than $20 for the whole dinner. Overall, the food is excellent, but it's not going to blow your mind. I see the appeal of Pequod's being a local favorite.

TL,DR - LONG wait line 1-2Hrs  (and 45 mins after ordering) Therese a reason why Chicago raves about pequad's they definitely know their pizza. I suggest a Pan Pizza and an appetizer while you wait. im not a Chicago native but will return here again, and gladly wait in line to grab a pizza. This place changed my thoughts on deep dish.I was on the fence about deep dish pizza as it always seemed like it would be a heavy meal, and it is. Its only good depending on who makes it.My gf decided i needed to try Pequod's while visiting Chicago. Gotta say, this place def changed my mind about deep dish. Wait time- Excessively long during nights, you may be looking upwards of 1-2 hour wait and another 45 mins before you get your food after placing the order. Interior - There is a downstairs area and a second floor as well. Downstairs seems a bit more crowded but has a larger bar. There is more room for tables and larger parties upstairs with a smaller bar. Just depends on preference. The place feels welcoming with a good down to earth and sports bar vibe.. dimly lit and plenty of screens to watch the game.We ended up getting a smaller pizza as there was 2 of us, this was recommended  by the waitress. We also ordered cheese bread which was to die for (or i think i was just starving) if youre impatient i suggest getting an appetizer. 1 Pan pizza - 3 toppings (Jalapeno, Pepperoni & Mushrooms) Ive seen deepdish before and what always turned me away was how greasy and runny the pizza would be. Pequad's was not the case! their pizza crust was crispy and held up quite nicely my fav by far. The sauce and toppings were not greasy or oily at all. I finished half the pizza (2 slices) before tapping out.

Excellent food!  We went for lunch and were excited to see the lunch special, 7in pan pizza for $4.95.  We started with the bruschetta which by presentation didn't look appealing, but the toast was garlic and buttery and the tomato relish was spot on.  Not a traditional brushchetta, but I would definitely order again.  I had the 7in pan cheese pizza and it was fantastic!  The sauce, crust and cheese were flavorful and unique.  My friend had the beef sandwich which she said was delicious.  Service was great and environment chill.  We will be back

Pequod's was recommended to us by locals as one of the best deep dish pizza places in Chicago. Pizzas are outstanding! Wait at the door is ~30min, pizza preparation time is ~40min, so make sure you got plenty time in hand when visiting. We ordered 2 medium size deep dish pizzas and few salads for a group of 6 people and it was just right!

I really liked this pizza. Pepperoni, sausage, sauce and crust were all delicious. The cheese that melts and burns on the edge of the pan and pizza is heaven. I had the personal pizza and I'm stuffed. Give yourself ample time to wait in line to be seated. Also to wait for the pizza to be made which usually takes 45-60 minutes.

deeee-lish deep dish! Pequod's was my welcome food to Chicago, and after having tried two others after, this is still on the top of my list. My cousins recommended this place, and it's easy to see why they rave over the deep dish pizza here- served in a cast iron skillet, with a burnt edge crust (just the top, really), they get the pizza right. Down to the sauce, the amount of cheese, and toppings- I'm drooling just writing about this! We were able to choose a half and half option, which was awesome! We went with spinach, mushrooms, and sausage for one half and pepperoni, garlic, and basil with the other half. Coupled with a pitcher of beer, this was the perfect afternoon! The pizza was finished, and now I'm wishing I was back in Chicago for more. Definitely would return!

Visiting Chicago... and why not check out the best foods this city has to offer! Voted #1 pizza... well there is a reason why it was labeled #1 on multiple lists. The pan pizza is amazing!!! I went with a medium pan pizza with pepperoni, sausage, meatballs, olives, extra sauce... and all well done. At first glance... mouth was watering... but it wasn't until that first bite, that I had that Disney Ratatouille moment. Every single flavor separate from the others, yet satisfyingly delicious. I'm glad I was able to make it here.

Complete and utter ridiculous policies and moron working the door. Can't accommodate no matter what, no give no take. Open tables and can't seat 2 children and an adult. Ridiculous and unacceptable. Open larger tables but reused to seat do to holding it for larger parties. The pizza here is typically great but their seating policies are crap. Won't let you order a pie while you're waiting for a table to expedite and be efficient. Completely upside down and backwards I came across the city and will not return. Not worth the parking headache, traffic, or senseless host. If there is a 30 minute wait and a 40 minute sign for pie, why not allow ordering? It'd turn your table faster. Crappy customer service, poor business efficiencies, good pie if you want to accept their BS seating.

Pequod's is now the 5th Chicago deep dish pizza joint I've tried in the past year. Though I'm by no means a die-hard deep dish fan, I still rather liked Pequod's and think it's my 2nd favorite deep dish (to find out which one is my fav, check out my other reviews ;))So what's good?- the SAUCE. I think it's one of my favs- generous toppings. when they give sausage, they give LOTS of sausage.- the giardiniera topping - YUMNow for the bad..- the thick crust. I get that there must be thick crust so all the toppings, cheese, and sauce are held together... but I just thought there was too much dough- I came a weds for lunch, so there was no wait (aside from the 45 mins for the pizza), but I imagine weekends to be a different story- it's not very cheap. it turned out to be $20/pp including drinks + tip + tax

I am writing this review more in terms of customer service rather than that of the quality of the food. We are frequent patrons of Pequod's Pizzeria and are apart of the community; however, I was unaware that this was not a family friendly place. We went to Pequod's at 6pm and were fine with the more than hour to hour and a half wait; however, once the time had expired we were met with an unfriendly host who had an attitude and prompted a very negative interaction and left a very negative view of the customer service we receive at Pequod's. As much as we love this pizza I do not feel we'll ever feel comfortable at this establishment.

I am more than willing to wait two hours for pizza but was extremely disappointed by what I was served. The crust was somehow rock hard yet when you finally chisel a piece away it tasted like undercooked corn meal. I am shocked this place made so many best of chicago lists.

I've been to a couple of different joints for deep dish and never quite cared enough but this though is a different league. The sauce was amazing though a little too wet to make eating not too messy. The cheesy garlic bread was great too. The crust was part cheese, adding to the flavour. Service? It was great. Our server checked in with my friend about the definitely drunk group next to us just to make sure everything was a-ok. It's rare that restaurants care if your neighbours are nice or not.My only unhappiness is that I've to wait to order my pizza. Guess I've been spoilt by how Lou Malnati let's you order them while waiting for a table.
Loved this place! The atmosphere was very laid back, the service was friendly, and the pizza amazing. Chicago style deep dish done perfectly.
That burnt crust is legit the best thing to happen to deep dish pizza. Real deal Chicagoans eat here.

I've heard this is some of the best pizza in Chicago. And if deep dish is your thing, this is for you. Great atmosphere. Pizza is baked in a cast iron skillet, ending up with a caramelized crust. I give it only 3 stars just because deep dish isn't my thing.

Ugh pizza here is super good! Crust is amazing!!! Laid back spot to have some pizza and drinks with your friends!! Or to watch a sports event! Something different and they have a lot of options of appetizers :)

Not a fan of Chicago deep dish pizza, but this place changed my mind.  Sometimes ill find myself craving the delicious caramelized crust pizza.  We usually tell our waiter/waitress to keep it in the oven for a little longer.  What I love about peaquods is the crust never gets soggy.  Its the right amount of sauce and generous toppings + its not overly cheesy like other places in the city. The wait is definitely worth it and the pizza tastes just as amazing the next day for left overs :) !!

Dine in only. Take out or delivery is awful. This place is typical bar and pizza. However the pizza is the best deep dish there is. A true Chicago classic that you need to check out. Better than lous and way better than giordanos IMO. full disclosure have not tried Chicago pizza oven grinder.

Great tasting sauce and amazing pull from cheese. All pizza is build your own and the are not stingy with the ingredients. This place is family approved!! Although, I wouldn't compare it Lou's because I remember Lou from my meat eating days but I heard they had great sausage as well. You can't beat the Lunch Deals either.

I was in Chicago for a visit and there were some tourist things I wanted to do like try deep dish pizza. However, I did want to do some research so I could at least try what many consider to be the best. Yes, there are other places that are considered to be the go to.But when I spoke with the Chicago locals, this place is the only place to go to for deep dish. I unfortunately can not speak too much for the place itself as far as ambience, atmosphere, service etc as I got an order to go. However, it did seem like a cozy joint to have some good pizza and have a good time. I ordered my deep dish over the phone and put like a million toppings so it came out to be about 30 bucks or so, but it was totally worth it. Even a day later, the leftovers were delicious. I love this place and can't wait to be back.

The food was awesome and our waitress, Noel, was even better.  The hostess Brenda, however, was the worst hostess ever.  We were starving and asked about ordering a large pan pizza while we waited to be seated so we wouldn't have to wait much longer to eat after being seated.  She said that it couldn't be done until we were seated.  After finally being seated, we asked to place the order for our pizza while our waitress became unoccupied due to the lack of waitresses to help her, but the miserable Brenda now said that we had to wait for our waitress.  Praise Noel!Get rid of Brenda or teach her some manners!

While they do get busy on the weekends, I have always had a good experience here. Head nextdoor to their bar for drinks and snacks while you wait to be seated in the restaurant. The pizza here is some of Chicago best and I always love their salad too. They do they're best to crank out deep dish pizza as fast as they could. I love that they are always clear and right on with their wait and pizza cooking times so that there is no confusion. It's definitely worth the wait. I recommend pepperoni and sausage in my pizza!

Decided to check this place out because of the reviews and fact that it was open late. We got the wings and cheesy bread for appetizers. The cheesy bread was a sub/hoagie roll with a bunch of cheese melted on top of it. It was okay. Nothing spectacular. Surprisingly they charge for the marina sauce that "comes with it"... weird. The wings came in two flavors. BBQ or buffalo. We went with BBQ and again was charged for the ranch dressing that "comes with it". When the deep dish pizza came out, so did my inner greedy person because my eyes got big and I got excited by the look of it. The waitress cut it and placed it on plates for us. I grabbed my fork and knife to grab a forkful of it and as soon as it hit my mouth, I felt betrayed. The flavor was good however, the crust took up half of the depth of the pie. I was definitely disappointed by that. The atmosphere of the place was good. It has a cool, laid back feel with pretty good music. Overall, it was okay but if you're looking for a deep dish pizza loaded with toppings and less crust, this isn't the place for you.

If I could eat only one dish before I died, you can bet that one dish would be pizza. With that said, I was a little disappointed with Pequod's pie. While visiting the great city of Chicago I knew I had to taste a legit Chicago Deep Dish. As I eagerly waited with the utmost excitement, my joy would soon turn into sorrow. As soon as our pie hit the table I could not wait to sink my teeth into my very first Chicago Deep Dish! However, as I carefully chewed on this Chigaco classic, I could not help but think, "hmm... this pizza literally tastes like a Pan Pizza from Pizza Hut." I get it... I understand the "nostalgic-ness" of Pequod's, and for that I completely respect it. In fact my 3-Star rating has nothing to do with the fact that our server was horrible. And I understand the excitement that patrons have for their trademark crust... but, to me, it did not live up to the hype.Overall, the pizza and experience was good not Great. Would I eat there again if I could? Most likely not. Would I recommend this place to others? Absolutely. All in all, I think that great food should leave you speechless, and with a sense of knowing that, "you'll never find a dish this f*#king good... not nowhere!" And Pequod's did not give me that feeling. Three Stars.

As a tourist from California, I came to Chicago to venture out deep dish pizza joints. After further research, I have concluded four original deep dish pizza from Chicago; Lou Manati, Uno, Pequods and Giordanos. See my other reviews of the other three and their respective ranking of the four godfathers of "Chicago Deep Dish Pizza". I will not grade on the service due to the fact that they were take outs + eaten within 20 minutes. Here is my take on Pequod;At $28, they were just a bit more pricey for aSmall size deep dish. Pizza: custom, all meat pizza The crust: solid, burnt but still had flavorSauce: Just about right Meat: all the meat literally was filling. The roast beef meat was the best! They did not cheap out Cheese: melted, okayAtmosphere: great for ages 20-35 crowd, nice ambience Parking: located further away from downtown, but yet close enough. Overall: I would have to rank Pequod second out of the four godfathers of "Chicago Deep Dish Pizza" places. Pros: the area is great, parking shouldn't be an issue. LOTS OF MEAT!Cons: could be more cheesy and less burnt crusts. Also if they could have a normal menu rather than a custom menuGrade: B

Not sure what all the hubbub is about.  It's usually at least an hour wait, and the pizza is good but not THAT good.  There are lots of pizza joints in Chicago, I can't say that this one is definitively the best

Got here on a Sunday night and the wait was about an hour. I've waited longer for food so I'm not that mad. Got seated up stairs and placed our order right away. Got cheese sticks for apps which were really good. Order a medium pan pizza with sausage and green peppers. I can tell they use fresh ingredients cause the green peppers tasted fresh. But here come the bad. The pizza had no flavor to me. It was just blend. Some bits I had were good but overall just blah! The ratio is completely off. There is just too much bread. Is that what a pan pizza is like? If so I'll pass on all pan pizza. Overall the place is cool but I truly can not understand what people see in this pizza. It's actually terrible. And don't get me started with the left overs: it's even worst when you reheat it up. Oh the sausage was great though but I wish there was more.

I was struggling to decide whether to go to this place or Lou Malnati's or Giordano's before I went to this place because I only had time to check out one of them. Eventually picked this place because my friends highly recommended this. I went there for lunch by myself. The lunch deal was really cheap (~$7 for 7"pan cheese pizza with two toppings and a drink). I had high expectations before I came here but the quality was just so-so. It reminded me of Pizza Hut pizza with a thicker crust. Was disappointed. I had deep dish pizza at Paxti's in San Francisco and I like that better. Sidenote: ordered diet coke but it had a weird taste, drank only a sip.
In the top 3 deep dish pizza spots in Chicago, hands down. Caramelized crust is delicious! Anytime someone visits from out of town, I take them here. Prepare to be full.

It was good times. I didn't have their famous pizza. I ordered an Italian beef sandwich and fries it was good. I like my Portillo's Italian beef more but it was fine. I like that their sandwich comes with a side of gravy because it taste better dipped.

Came here on a Sunday around 4pm on a day that the cubs played in Chicago, so we had no wait. They warned us that the wait for deep dish pizza would be 40 minutes, so we were expecting that. The pizza, for all of the hype that it was given, was not worth the price in my option. It's $19 for plain cheese and then $3 for extra toppings, which is kind of ridiculous. Our server switched mid sitting, which was weird, so our second server never came to fill up our water until we asked. Overall a very mediocre experience and not a place I will come back to.

Made a reservation because there seems to always be a long wait. We arrived and still had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. My friend and I shared a small DD. It took about 50 minutes to arrive at the table. The pizza was good; heavy on the sauce and the cheese are was bit spread out. Enjoyed the copious amounts of toppings! Service was friendly. I give it 4 stars because we were seated right next to a garbage can which was kind of gross.

Pequods uses low quality ingredients. Not convinced? Order a thin crust pizza and see how greasy it is.Their gimmick is the carmelized crust, which after you have once you realize is gummy and just not good. Look, those that know pizza, know that Pequods is one thing - and that's all HYPE. One final comment - I have never seen a filthier establishment. Garbage is everywhere.

The wait was worth it!   (It was only about 15 mins on a Friday afternoon around 2:00 pm)  It's wheelchair accessible, if you let them know and the pizza is good!  I got a personal pan with a couple toppings and it was good!  It's does have a thick crust but you don't really even notice.  It has a great balance of crust, sauce and cheese.  Very good!

As a New Yorker. I take pride in my hometown pizza. I'm no brat about it, but at the same time. Deep dish pizza is not pizza. As one friend put it, it's bread lasagna.However, I do like my deep dish pizza. So on my first visit to the windy city, I was told this was the best place for deep dish.My friend and I split a small, half regular, half sausage & onion. Boy howdy does this stuff fill you up! Every bite makes you want to take another one. Pequods is certainly the king of deep dish pizza in Chicago!If you ever pass thru this city, I'd absolutely check it out. You won't be disappointed

Came here saturday night around 6 PM and this place was paaaacked. Wait to dine in was an hour and then another 1.5 hour for your pizza to be made. We made an executive decision to carry out so we could eat faster heheWe ordered a small with mushrooms and then went across the street to Kibbitznest (which you should totally do if you have a long wait because that place is awesome).It took a little longer than what they quoted us so when we went back they surprised us with a large pizza woooooop Took it home and devoured it. Personally i'm a thin crust fan (east coast represent) so I'm generally suspicious of deep dish. But I was surprised they actually had a decent amount of sauce unlike other deep dish I've had. Mushrooms were really good and the cheese crust was phenomenal. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was how dry the bread is. But all in all, would come back for this lunch special I hear so much about.

Okay so this isn't my personal favorite place for deep dish but I do find myself coming here often bc it's where my husband likes to bring our out of town guests for deep dish. The crust here is more caramelized which I like but I don't consider this fully deep dish. It's really good though so I'd recommend!
Great pizza, just don't love the burnt crust.

I brought 2 of my friends to Pequod's on a Saturday around 2pm after my fiancé told me that they serve some of the best deep dish pizza in Chicago. It was super packed but the hostess was very efficient. We ended up waiting for about 10 minutes at the bar until our table was ready. We ordered a deep dish pizza (idr what size or type lol it's been a month) but I do know that it was pretty delicious. Our waitress was really nice and the place felt like a 70s pizza parlor lol. I like it a lot and will be back one day when I feel like waiting for great deep dish.

This was the best pizza place I've been to in Chicago. We went on Mother's Day around noon and was able to sit without waiting! I heard the lines get insanely long so we were super lucky. We ordered a small and medium for 4 people and it was more than enough. We had leftovers. For the pan pizzas, we ordered sausage, meatballs, and jalapeños for one and onion, pepperoni, mushroom, and onions for the other. Both were sooo good. Will miss this place!

Was in Chicago recently and of course had to get deep dish pizza.  I had read a lot of articles about Pequod's being the best and were they right! I was scared we woukd have to wait a long time as it was. Thursday night but we got seated after 15 mins.My boyfriend and I ordered the pepperoni and sausage pizza and boy was it delicious.  The crust is caramelized and has a little bit of a crunch too it.  Full of flavor and they don't skimp out on the toppings.  I was full after just once slice but it was too food so ate another.Would recommend over Giordanos and Lou Malnatis. It is the best deep dish I've ever had!

Pequod's is a Bar that serves Pizza. Plain and simple. It is a very specific kind of Chicago pizza (you won't have to search very hard for the pictures) that incorporates a very airy dough, tall (deep-dish) execution, crispy-crunchy edges, and not a whole lot of cheese on top. As far as the setting, Pequod's looks and feels like a dive bar. Fortunately for Pequod, it is a good dive bar and it does what it does very well. I got what I came for, and didn't really expect anything different. It is a solid place if you want to go throw a few back and eat some pizza with friends. Honest (and very likely unpopular to many) opinion? The pizza isn't anything to write home about. It's good enough, but you have to really want this kind of pizza, else you'll be disappointed. The bartenders and servers I encountered were friendly, helpful, and swift. Service was great and I had a great time. If I were in Chicago again I'd probably try someone else's take on the indigenous pizza, but Pequod's is a good choice for those seeking the experience.

Hands down the best pizza I have ever had, and I have had tons of pizza. I looked forward to coming here after seeing the restaurant featured on countless tv shows.
