My favorite pizza in Chicago! As a Chicagoan, born and raised, this place is the best in town! They only have 2 locations (one city and one burbs), making it even more desirable. The fact that they are exclusive to Chicago is what I love about this place! The Chicago location is a bit cozy so try to keep your party under 4. Otherwise getting a table is going to be 1. Very Hard! Like... incredibly, super duper hard!   2. You'll get to know your friend really really well.  The seats are kind of tight too, so hang your winter coats at the hallway coat hangers.  It'll save up the space for the very cozy booth seat for 4.Get the sausage pizza cause that's the best!  Their sausage is seasoned differently.  It's a little sweet, with a touch of anise.  And the crust of this pizza is the best!  The cheese is caramelized within the crust!  Unlike any other Chicago Pizza, the crust is thinner and chewier.  It's not too fluffy and not over dough-y.  The balance between crust, cheese, and filling is perfect!

I've loved Pequod's ever since I was little and my mom would bring home a pizza after work from their suburban location.  Now that I live close to Lincoln Park I try to go here every once in a while.  I won't get into an argument about the best deep dish in Chicago but just know that no discussion is complete without someone mentioning Pequod's.The place gets crowded so last time I was strategic and arrived just as the Hawks game was finishing.  This was perfect as everyone was leaving and tables were opening up left and right.  We opted to sit at the bar.  We were told the pizza would take like 40 minutes so we ordered mozzarella sticks.  The pizza came out about 20 minutes later so I was pretty bummed we ordered an app, which I wouldn't have done had I known the pizza would be out soon.  I guess that's a good upselling technique on their part but I didn't have enough room for delicious pizza.  Tell your rumbling tummy to shut up (or hold it over with beer) and wait for the pizza.  They also have a really good salad, if you're into that kind of thing.

This was a recommend by one of our friends that used to live in Chicago and I'm glad she told us about it as we wouldn't have otherwise checked it out.  Best deep dish we had in Chicago hands down!  The caramelized crust alone should win awards.  We came early so there weren't many people when we arrived but there was a line when we left so get there early.I'd come back to Chicago just to have another pizza from here.
The pan pizza is a staple and the thin crust isn't too far behind.The dining service has always been so-so (My party invested 3 hours one time due to waitstaff errors).Overall a great place.
I prefer Pequod's over Lou's. The one thing I will say is that eating it there out of the pan is much better than getting delivery or take out!

This is one of the best pizza places I've been to! The food is amazing and the service is pretty fast for a deep dish pizza place. I ordered the cheese fries and an Italian beef pizza. The fries were delicious pizza was surprisingly super great. This place is so underrated.

Listen here, you must understand that this is a super busy and popular pizza joint that cooks deep dish pizzas (longer cook time) and you should proceed with caution and patience. This place is in no way a fine dining establishment so if you are looking for a wine list, a cloth napkin, and a server to be kissing your hand and feet as you enter, then this is not the place for you. This is a fun, busy, crowded and loud sports bar. The pan pizza is delicious, the apps are great, and there are a million TV's. It's so easy to see snotty and impatient customers around you not understanding why the pizza is taking so long? Or complaining about no wine list? Or that it's too loud, or too hot, or too crowded, or blah blah blah! Come on, take it as it is, have fun and enjoy the experience! Pequods will always have a place in my heart! Also, GO BLACKHAWKS!

The fam and I tried this fine pizza establishment while visiting in April. The pizza crust was thick and flavorful with a cheesy crunch. We (five of us) ordered a large and could not finish our pizza. They have a bunch of flat screen TV's on the walls so this would be a great place to have drinks, and food and enjoy a game. Our waitress was friendly and quick and we enjoyed our meal here.
The Italian beef and sausage sub was just incredible. The deep dish was great too - kids loved it, but I'm a thin crust guy. Great ingredients, service, and atmosphere. A must for a Chicago visit.

Pequods pizza was a bit disappointing, I'm already not a fan of deep dish pizza (New York Pizza all day e'ry day) but when in Rome...Pequods supposedly has an amazing crust, I must disagree, my crust had a doughy consistency (like not completely cooked, but come on, you made me wait 40 minutes for it...) the toppings were stingy and I paid for a premium topping (meatball) and barely got any.  The pizza seemed under seasoned and just was pretty meh.  The meatball I must say was tasty, it wasn't tough and and a decent flavor on its own but not enough to carry the pizzaService wasn't terrible but wasn't amazing either...

Hands down the best deep dish/ pan pizza in the city. Been here 4-5 times and every time I leave craving more pizza but so stuffed. Decent selection of local beers as well. Come here early or on a week night because there will almost always be a wait and if you call for delivery and phone is busy, they are open but will not take your order because they are so busy. Would give this place  10 stars if I could.

Oh Pequod's, you frustrate me so much....This is definitely my favorite deep dish pizza in chicago.  The sauce/cheese ratio is exactly what i'm looking for and the caramelized crust is incredible.  However, I have had a few experiences with bad service.  If you want to have the best experience here, get take out or sit at the bar.My last pequod's experience was ordering delivery:  I was told the delivery would take an hour and a half, which is standard for pequod's since their pizza takes a while to make.  After 2 hours, i tried to call to check on my delivery, no answer.  After another half hour, I gave up on the expectation of getting my pizza at all.  The next day i emailed them to request a refund to my credit card, which was done a few days later.  But no response to my email, no apology,  or anything at all.I am generally pretty patient: if I received a call the night of the delivery saying "hey, something happened with our driver, we have to cancel your order"  then i would have been disappointed, but understanding.  What bothers me is the lack of communication, and wasting of my time.  If you can't handle deliveries, don't offer delivery.

It's frickin' good pizza.  I thought nothing could beat Lou Malnati's but I was wrong.  A co-worker suggested I try this spot and the pizza didn't disappoint.  I ordered one with extra cheese, basil, and sausage.  That frickin' sausage was to die for.  And the burnt crust at the end was really good.  I'm sorry I wasn't able to take a pic of it since my phone died.  We each at a slice and was so full we packed it and decided to give to a homeless person.  Was happy someone could make a meal out of it.

Came in a bit after midnight right after the Cubbies took game 1 of the NLCS - surprised that we did not have a wait. We were immediately seated and placed our order shortly thereafter. While it does take a bit of time to get your order out (I think anticipation makes the wait seem longer than it actually is) it was absolutely worth the wait!Can't wait to get back to Chicago soon and this will definitely be a place I would head back to everytime for deep dish.

After hearing all of the hype about Peaqud's, I was in the area last weekend and decided to give it a try.  I ordered a pan pizza with sausage and mushrooms.  I do like the crust very much, however the sauce and toppings were a disappointment.  Also be aware that although the crust is very good when the pizza is fresh, it doesn't taste the same when reheated.

Yummy in my tummy! I have been coming here for take out for about a year now and I love it!  I usually order the same thing every time which is the deep dish pepperoni pizza with extra sauce! The sauce they use is rich, seasoned right and just plain delicious, so that's why I say extra sauce!!! The caramelized onion crust is what makes these pizza's perfect! The most recent visit was unforgettable! I ordered a pizza for pick up and I arrived early. So, I told the hostess I will be waiting in my car and I will come back in 10 minutes. As I was waiting she knocks on my car window to deliver me my pizza! Now that is worth 5 stars!! If you are looking for somewhere different for deep dish that isn't Lou or Gino east.. Come to the north side of Chicago and experience a different style of pizza with outstanding service.
This is Chicago's BEST deep dish pizza. Period. I've lived here for 28 years and nothing comes close. Definitely worth the often very long wait.

They are getting 2 stars because I know how great their pizza can be...Unfortunately, I didn't even have the chance to eat here the other night:I made a reservation last week with a very friendly hostess over the phone - and all was great, and I was looking forward to taking my family that was visiting from out of town.We showed up at 6pm on a Sunday (our reservation time). One of the FIVE... yes FIVE hostesses standing there told me it would be atleast another 45 minutes. They then went on to tell me that they don't take reservations. WHAT?!? They tried explaining that 'I was jumping the wait-list with my called-in reservation from the week before'. (which by the way, if this is a 'thing'- this arrangement was never brought to our attention over the phone and we thought we were making a NORMAL reservation)That night, we ate at Giordanos and it was wonderful.Pequod's has definitely lost me as a patron with their poor customer service, ridiculousness to reservations/no reservations, and for having 5 hostesses (go bus a table and help out your fellow servers!)

We tried two deep dish places, Pequod's and Giordano's. We were a little disappointed by Giordano's, but Pequod's more than made up for it. They are totally two different pizzas. Giordano's is a layered pizza like a lasagna. Pequod's is like a traditional pizza with a thick crust. We tried the pepperoni and it was delicious! The caramelized crust is amazing.They also had an alcoholic root beer, which tasted exactly like root beer. The atmosphere was chill and didn't feel touristy like Giordano's. This is the Chicago deep dish to try.

After a full day of drinking, walking, shopping, and doing touristy things, I was delirious by the time we arrived here for dinner so I can't accurately comment on anything prior to the food, but hey that's all that matters.From what I -do- remember, ambiance was nice (I felt cozy, and cozy is always a good thing for me), service was very friendly. The only poopoo was that our appetizer was forgotten until after our pizza came, but it was comp'd so I can't say shat. Will not beat a dead horse and rave about how DELICIOUSSS the pie was (burnt. crust. ohmygahd), except to say that pizza is forever ruined for me. Perhaps I'm biased because this is probably the only real pizza I've had, but for now I truly mean it. Would find any excuse to visit Chicago just so I can come back.
This is the best pizza around!  Beyond good!  Order the deep dish and you'll smile with every single bite!!!

Great place, great food, today unfortunately the service did not meet up to par. Waitress/server Never gave her name and just seemed to be in a rush. Our order was taken and she made sure we always had drinks but a bit friendlier would've worked too. When you get charged for a slice of cake for a birthday girl, you know this ain't the place to celebrate in the future.

Well.  This is my second time here.  First with the wife and now with the boys.  I love the deep dish.  What a relaxed place and good environment.  Pizza takes 50 min.  But if you relax and have good people to chat with, it's all good.
First time in Chicago and everyone told us to come here. Expected more from this place but a lot of people love it.

I'm not a big fan of deep dish, but I liked this spot! You can get individual sized pizza and they have lots of different toppings. Also loved the vibe of the place and they had lots of craft beer on draft to choose from! If you are having a hard time picking a deep dish Chicago style spot, this is the place to go!

The wait to even get the pizza was very ridiculous. It took 2 hours for pick up. I expected a lot more from their pizza since the wait was so long, but unfortunately I was disappointed. Maybe it's because I'm not a fan of really thick crusted pizza? So maybe I'm a little bias. But this pizza was just way too doughey for me. The flavor of the pizza was also okay. I've read a lot of reviews saying we should add extra sauce and extra cheese, but that was probably the worst decision to be made. Too much sauce and cheese and not enough meat. The ingredients were definitely fresh though. I give them that.

I went to Pequod's for the first time about a month ago. The pizza was not for me but people love it. The cheese to bread ratio is very uneven. There is so much bread and it is kind of dry. The one thing i did like was they make great homemade ranch. If you like a very "bready" pizza then this is the place for you.

Been coming here for years and despite the lack of parking and the long wait times, we keep coming back because the pizza is just that good!  This place is well run and employees are well trained by the manager who is a fixture here!  He runs a tight ship and leads by being a hands on perfectionist in an environment that could easily be chaotic and unmanageable!  Kudos to him.
My personal favorite deep dish in Chicago.

1970's Chicago deep dish pizza in a 1980's atmosphere.    I remember places like this when I was a child growing up in Chicago.   Pequod's is one of the only deep dish pizza joints remaining that I consider to be authentic.PROS:1.   Possibly the very best example of classic Chicago deep dish pizza, evoking memories of my childhood 40 years ago.2.   It's delicious!3.   The menu is everything you'd expect.   It's almost as if a committee got together and spent a year coming up with the most prototypical pizza joint menu.    CONS:1.  Success hasn't ruined this place, but it sure is crowded.    If you are a bigger group and plan ahead, you can sometimes get your name in for a big table.    But if there is just two of you, expect a very long wait, and to get stuck in a claustrophobic table if you are unlucky.  2.   The location is really only good if you live in the area, or are visiting nearby Webster Place.    Nothing convenient about Clybourn Avenue.   (The good pizza is worth it though!)Visit this place during an off-peak time, and take a cheese-filled trip back to the Chicago of the Richard J. Daley era.    If you grew up here, you may find a bit of yourself in this place.

My party ordered a salad, cheese bread, large deep dish meat and small deep dish veggie. Also a pitcher of beer.I loved the sauce and meat, as well as the cheesy bread we got. The dipping sauce that came with the cheese bread was almost drinkable it was so good.However, the crust reminded me of Pizza Hut, thick and greasy. I had never had Chicago deep dish pizza but heard all the hype. Was not impressed. Our appetizer cheese bread came out after our pizzas which was already an hour wait. I was sat in this corner under a neon light that felt at least 10 degrees warmer than the rest of the restaurant. Also, our waitress never once offered to refill drinks nor get us a round of waters. The staff "uniforms" were confusing since everyone wears a different color shirt. It was tough to figure out who worked here. Overall, I'd eat it for delivery, but probably not come back in.

Just what you ever dreamed of for deep dish pizza. I had this delivered during my first try and was a bit disappointed but decided it was worth another shot. Have been to the restaurant twice now and am obsessed. I have ordered pepperoni and pepperoni/mushroom and both were phenomenal. A small is definitely big enough for two. Definitely call before OR order an appetizer because the pizzas take a bit to bake. Skip Lou's and Giordano's which is basically just a chain now and head to Pequods. You really won't be disappointed.

Ok i read so many great things about this place, was gonna go to Berts but didnt want to travel the extra distance, considering he started Pequads I figured it would be close. Well this one going down in institutional longevity, which means they been around so long they sucked the locals into thinking they were good. Tasted like a flavorless piece of Italian bread with spaghetti sauce on it, and some burnt cheese on edge of crust. Disappointing. Lous kills you by miles.

Had my daughter's first birthday party here the other week. We had 30 adults and 10 kids. Party was upstairs in the private room in back which has a number of booths. Reserving the space was easy, just did it online and also got an email from Sean. I had a ton of questions and he replied quickly. We decided to order off the menu. We ordered baked mostaccioli with marinara sauce, pitches of soda and 12 pizzas. Ordered both the thin and the pan. All different kinds of toppings. Food came out when we requested it, service was great. Janet was the main server and she was so nice and attentive. Everyone loved the food and it was a good time. For the amount of food we ordered and the number of guests, the cost wasn't bad at all and food really did taste great. Thin was crispy, pan was nice and cheesy and had a nice caramelized crust!It's nice that the room doesn't have an amount of time you can have it for. We set up at 11am, party started at 1230. Food was out like I requested at 1pm and the party was over around 3:30 and we got our stuff together and left by 4. The room has 2 tvs so the guys were able to watch games. I would have a party here again, too bad there wasn't more parking in the area, but it's the city!
The best pizza in Chicago. Worth the wait as the caramelized crust is to die for! We went at 11 AM Saturday morning and it was dead.

Be. Prepared. To. Wait. (no matter the hour)Good deep dish, not the greatest in Chicago.  Dough is a bit bland as is the sauce.  Make sure you add lots of yummy toppings to make the pizza worthwhile.  Would I eat here again? Yes.  Would I choose this pizza over another place? No.

Definitely an upgrade from Giordanos which I've been told no self-respecting Chicagoan would find himself or herself eating at (whoops for me). It was still the 45 minute wait for food, but the pizza quality was definitely noticeably better. The staff and service were great and the happy hour seems like an awesome nice touch. I can't really comment on the pizza other than it was tasty and better than the last Chicago pizza joint I was at.Space can be tight so coming at off hours can definitely help get you a table faster. You might also have to get creative with where you park (farther from the restaurant) iif you're an outta towner like me.
I don't like deep dish pizza but this is definitely the tastiest I've had and, oh man, that crust! But we had a rather unfriendly waitress when we went so I have to subtract a star

I heard good things about this place. So we decided to order take out. We had 9 pickup orders, mostly personal pans and one was incorrect. I feel that you'd have to eat there for the full experience, but the lady through the phone order was quite short with me. The pizza was alright overall, but service was only satisfactory. Parking is abysmal in this area.

I stopped here for lunch with a friend. The pizza was good and the price was right. I also like that it's BYOB! I ordered the lunch special, they make it fresh so it takes a little while but it is hot and delicious. I will be stopping again, Check it out if your in the area.
Great pizza good environment, awesome beer. The waitress was nice, also the wait is a bit long but well worth it.

Excellent example of Chicago deep dish. Decent zucchini fries too. Great beer selection. Fun servers. If I have a complaint it is that it feelsLike it takes forever to get that pie you were dying for a half hour ago.

Overrated. Maybe it was because I got a to go order though.Had to wait 30 mins at the store after their quoted pick up time.They then forgot my appetizer combo and had to make it "fresh".But when I got home everything was super soggy and luke warm.Will try again but eat in store this time.

This is my first review of Pequod's after two visits. This place is way up there in the Chicago deep dish hierarchy, and it is well deserved!First tip, this place gets really busy on the weekends. Time for a pizza can be 45-60 mins, even much later on in the evening. But it's worth it! The first time I went I got green pepper, sausage and pepperoni. It was delicious! The crust is really unique at Pequod's and the meat was SO good in this pizza. The second time I got just sausage, which I didn't like as well. I recommend getting multiple toppings, it just adds more flavor.This is a must visit place in Chicago. The pizza is outstanding and the building itself has a lot of character. I will definitely be going back again and again.
Since moving out from Chicago, the two things I miss the most are Portillos and Pequods. Nothing else compares to the crust and sausage you get here.

Let me start of by saying pizza is not one of my favorite foods, but I do consider myself a pizza connoisseur. I back this up by saying that I grew up with a father that loved pizza. Loves pizza so much. We frequently traveled to new pizza places always trying what's new and highly rated. So, with that being said, I have a strong opinion of "good pizza" - I do believe there is bad pizza. Pequod's is the opposite of bad, it's one of the best. The ingredients are super fresh and I would go as far to say the best sausage I have ever had on a pizza. Besides, Burt's Pizza, who was the guy that opened Pequod's and then went to a smaller pizza location in the burbs until recently, when sadly he passed away. The pizza was delicious, yes it is doughy, if that isn't your style, you may not enjoy this. Mike, my boyfriend, wanted to make sure I mentioned how great the crust is, in his words "it's top-notch" (I don't eat crusts). My only complaint is the garlic bread. How can you have such delicious pizza and such below average garlic bread.  Will we be back, absolutely. Pequod's definitely hits the spot and fills your pizza craving.

I went here on a pizza tour a year ago and thought it was fantastic so I was really excited to come back. I felt really let down today. Waited an hour for a table.  Once we sat down and placed our order we knew it would be about another hour so we got their garlic cheesy bread,  it's worse than the frozen stuff from the grocery store. It was rock hard and was only made edible because of the sauce we got with it. When our pizza came it was obviously overdone. The bottom layer of crust was black.  Even if I peeled off the burnt parts it was still dry and lacked flavor. Just utterly disappointing after a 2 hour wait.

The BEST deep dish Chi city has to offer.  I had to go gluten-free due to some health issues and losing this pains me the most. Sometimes I think the fatigue, bloating, and atomic farts might be worth cheating for!
Mediocre  pie . Tonight has an hour wait, maybe 3 dozen people waiting outside and 13 (13!) Booths with No one  seated at them.  Room for about 65.... fail.
Pizza was marginal and service was average at best. Heard a lot of good things about this place from the locals,but it definitely didn't live up to the hype. One and done for me.

Friendly greeting upon arrival, got there early enough that the wait time was only 15 minutes. Started with the cheese sticks, they were good and served their purpose, take the edge off while waiting for our pizza. Ordered a deep dish with sausage, onion and green pepper. It was very good, but it could have used more cheese. Overall it's a great pizza with a unique flavor.

Last week was my first time eating deep dish pizza. There were so many options of pizza in Chicago. After reading so many reviews on whether it was better to eat at the tourist chain restaurants or driving out to Pequod's, we decided to listen to the locals.  We went on a Monday night and even though they didn't seem too busy we still had to wait a while to be sat. Keep in mind your pizza will take an additional hour to make after you have put your order in. I was with a group of 5 and we ordered the mozzarella sticks and the garlic cheese bread. The mozzarella sticks were nothing specials but the garlic cheese bread was so good and got us even more excited about the pizza we ordered.  Our pizza definitely did not disappoint! We were so stuffed. We ordered two large pizzas and we were not able to finish one! We did not get a chance to visit Giordanos or Lou malnati's, so I can't compare the pizza to theirs but we were definitely happy with our experience at Pequod's.I did take a star off for service, our waiter was very snappy. Took too long checking in on us and bringing us our drinks.
Always good!   A must try!! The best Carmelized pizza crust!  And if you can order ahead pizzas take at least 45 minutes.. But so worth it

It's seriously just a pan pizza. It's not amazing or anything special. I feel bad saying something bad about a restaurant. It's good pizza but I don't think it was worth the price... I like flavorful foods and unique food. I had to put salt on my pizza. If your ever thinking "man I want some decent pizza" this is the place for you! It's alright nothing spectacular or anything to rave about.

Not much more to add besides I loved the pizza. Personal size is the right amount for one hungry person. Also, well priced for the quality you get. About $10 for a personal size with two toppings. The caramelized edges are the cherry on top of a fine pizza.
The crust has the consistency of a fluffy biscuit + caramelized, the tomato sauce is light and sweet (not salty) makes for an incredible deep dish pizza, not as cheesy and saucy as the others.

This place used to be great but they have been overwhelmed and have not figured out how to deal with the volume.  I ordered a pizza at 5:30 on a Saturday night and was told it would be 1:20.  I showed up at 6:50 and waited for an hour, asking three times if there was an update on my order and getting no answer, before I got two pizzas that had obviously been sitting in the warmer for quite some time.  Very disappointing.

I guess I'll be generous and give this place 4 stars instead of 3.  I rate it at 3.5  The pizza came out relatively quickly, or at least it seemed like it.  I wasn't a huge fan of the crust, but the top outside edge where the cheese carmelized was pretty tasty.I still love the deep dish pizza from home (Zachary's and Little Star in Berkeley) I always compare deep dish to them and they are still the best in my opinion.I was in Chicago for a 5 day trip and wanted to try out some of the best rated and highly recommended pizza places.I liked Lou Malnati's better than this place, but this was still a good option.The service was good.Sorry for the boring review...

Hype. I really wanted to like it because people rave about it, but its just not good. First of all. This is not deep dish pizza. Its pan pizza. So if you're expecting a pizza like Lou's or Giordano's, go there, because this is not the deep dish you know and love. Pequod's pizza is more like a focaccia bread, very doughy, with a little bit of sauce and toppings and a hint of cheese. If you cut it in half it would probably make great sandwich bread. What toppings there are, are very fresh and of good quality.The best part of the pizza is the burnt cheese on the crust. Burnt cheese crust really shouldn't be the highlight of your deep dish pizza though. The wait is usually long and even if you place your order ahead of time, you'll likely be waiting anyway. Its like they're doing you a favor serving you bread with some sauce on it. Skip Pequod's and Burt's Place for that matter and go anywhere else for pizza.

Hate to be hard on a small business, but this is NOT Chicago-style deep dish pizza. The "deep dish" option was just a thicker crust. I mean this pizza was so bad I took the time to take a picture and warn my Chicago friends. Would I be mad if I bought this for $10? No. But I paid a lot more than $10. Save yourself the time and money and get a gas station za instead.

I first saw of this place on man vs food and thought I have to try this place. I am glad I did!! This place can get packed but luckily my husband and I beat the lunch rush on a Saturday and got a table quickly. Our server told us their pizzas take about 45 minutes so we put our order in and started with mozzarella sticks. They were pretty average. Our pizza finally arrives and on my goodness, DELICIOUS! The pizza is definitely worth the wait. It is so thick and the dough has a sort of sweet flavor to it which is amazing. My only complaint is our server was beyond rude. We asked for clean plates after our appetizers and that really pissed her off. So much so I saw and heard her complaining about us to the bartender. She didn't ask how our food was during our meal but sure did perk up when it was time to drop the check. Other than her nasty attitude, the place is great. We will definitely be back our next trip to Chicago.
Great thin crust pizza!!!! Definitely worth a visit!!!

Maybe it's the crust... Maybe it's the insides of pure gooey heavenmaybe it's that I can put whatever the fuck I want inside (haha) what am I describing here?! A GOOD DAMN PIZZA I love deepdish. I know Giordano's is supposed to be the best or even Lou mal- but I really never like their deepdish the way I love Pequod's. They are good until you come here. And than a little light in your head turns on. And you realized you were settling for less! They have Chicago beer and Chicago pizza. And they keep this city girl happy :)

Dear Pequod's, You are the sand to my beach, the peanut butter to my jelly, the wind beneath my wings. No but for real. Today was a great experience of many at this wondrous pizzeria. Although we waited almost thirty unbearable minutes to get seated, it was all worth it. Emily, our server, made us laugh! And not like, AT her. WITH HER. She was timely, well informed, and helpful. Our nervous, yet very cool busboy, James, was fantastic! It was his first day on the job, but he even remembered my boyfriend's request for blue cheese when I had forgotten. The appetizers came at just the right time and temperature. Our beers were brought cold and filled to the brim. The pizza was perfect! Caramelized crust, melty cheesy goodness, filled with the right amount of pepperoni and spinach. Just the way I like it! Pequod's is hands down the best place to bring a newbie for some Chicago style pizza. The atmosphere is great for every kind of person. Not too sporty, not too hipster, and not too yuppie. I recommend to all!

Use to always buy from here, it was one of our favorite places for pizza. Thank God it's not our only place we like to order from. Ordered our normal double pepperoni pizza, extra pizza sauce, extra cooked. Gave my name, exact address including my apartment number and then proceeded to wait for our pizza to be delivered. We waited and waited but our pizza never came. We finally fell asleep a little after 1:00 a.m. Woke up the next morning and had two missed calls from Peqoud's, one at 1:23am and another at 1:30am. I called in my order at 11:48pm. So I called Peqoud's again tonight to explain that we paid for our pizza but never even got a knock on the door, despite me giving them my apartment number(we have a door man to let them into the lobby by the way so no excuse for not coming to our apartment.) The nice lady who answered the phone explained the situation to the manager on duty tonight(Friday night on August 4, 2017) and informed me that the manager said they tried to call twice but I never picked up the phone so they are not responsible for us not receiving the product that we already paid for. I am a professional in the hospitality industry and I am appalled at the response by the management at Pequod's. You expect your customers to not only pay you for a product, but then do the extra work of chasing you down to make sure they receive it? I apologize Pequod's, but I was never taught that this was the way a hospitality establishment was to conduct itself while I was majoring in Hospitality and Tourism Management at Purdue University. Maybe that's why we always rank in the top of the nation for our School of Hospitality and Tourism Management because we choose to educate our future industry leaders on proper etiquette in this industry. I don't want to insult another school by attempting to guess where you source your managers from, but they'd never make it past the first interview if it were my business. So, as happy as I would like to be to continue ordering from you, I will not be doing so for I have little tolerance for bad customer service. That includes not ordering from you for my employees when they work late as I have done the last two months.

What a gem! I love the vibe in Pequods, the staff, & the food. Normally I am not a fan of their pizzas, but I do find that their pasta is AMAZING!! I love how this Chicago pizza place separates themselves from the others. It's definitely worth a stop!!
Great Pizza, use lots of napkins, as it can get messy. Burnt cheese crust is a nice touch

Left feeling a little underwhelmed unfortunately.  I love both Giordano's and lou's for deep dish so I wanted to try the other deep dish place I kept hearing rave reviews about.  Firstly, our buzzer never went off for our table so once we finally realized that people who had come in after us were being seated, we politely approached the host who then seated us right away.  Not a big deal and not the workers' faults at all but not the best start.  Mozz sticks as an appetizer were good but the pizza was just slightly disappointing.  It was a little dry on the bottom and I kinda wish we had gotten extra cheese on it as the sauce to cheese ratio wasn't great.  I would come back, but I think I'll stick to some other deep dish staples.

We had waited over an hour for seating our group of 7... they do not take resv, walk in only.  The pizza pies were incredible!! The only thing was they had recommended 3 pies for our party and we only finished 2.  Trust me ... we tried! It was very cheesy and tasty!!

As a Chicagoan, I'm embarrassed to admit that I just had my very first Pequod's experience last weekend. I can't believe I've been missing out on this much goodness for this long! Pequod's is a jam-packed pizza place, and for good reason! Their pizza is the ooey-gooeyist of all the Chicago style pizzas. Their famous carmelized crust is just as good as everyone says it will be, and their tomato sauce is hearty and flavorful! If you come to this location in the City, be prepared to wait! They do not take reservations but do have a priority list, which cuts down the wait time. We came in on a Sunday evening and waited about 40 minutes for a table, and again about 45 minutes for the pizza to come out. While the atmosphere is definitely divey, and while the place is jam-packed, it's worth it to experience the greatest of the Chicago deep dish options.

I love pizza!! I went to this place about twice the first time I was very happy because we were able to get seated right away and the food didn't take too long to come out. The second time I came to this place there were less people and for some reason our food took forever to come out and they tried charging us for water. I'm never a person to really point things out like this but I found it very distrubing that we didn't get the best service that night. But other than that the pizza was great.

This pizza is delicious. Gooey, cheesy, perfect. The tomato sauce is sweet and bright, and the crust is buttery beyond belief. We added garlic, mushrooms, and spinach to the pizza, and split between four people (and still had leftovers!) We ordered a salad as an app, and the cheese came shaped like a whale (in honor of the restaurant's namesake). So cute!!
Good luck with delivery here. Waited over two hours and was lied to about the pizza being on its way. Will NEVER order from this place again.
Not a huge deep dish fan, but if you like deep dish, this is the creme de la creme
Wait time is always really long whether you're picking up or waiting to be seated. The pizza seems pretty average to below-average to me, not sure what the hype is all about.
Where the locals go and for good reason. The crust is bomb. Worth the wait, but if you go on an off day. We got seated right away!
Whoever answers the phone for late night delivery is a total butthole. Cool customer service guys.

Three and a forty-five minutes. That's how long it took. We arrived at 5:15p on a Saturday and was told it would be an hour and a half wait. Took 2 hours and three times asking to get a seat. Then after we sat, took and hour and a forty-five minutes before we got the pizza. By the time we got the food, we didn't even want to eat it. It was good pizza, but not good enough to wait almost 4 hours.

So Lou Malnati's was my favorite deep dish pizza place in Chicago.... I thought no other deep dish could compete.... I WAS WRONG. Pequods.... wow.  I really don't know what else to say that hasn't already been said about their amazing pizza.  The sauce... the fresh toppings... that crust!!!I will happily drive from the suburbs to carryout from here.  I suggest you all do the same !
Hands down my favorite pizza place in Chicago! Good brews, amazing caramelized crust and a fun environment! This is my go-to rec for people looking for the best in Chicago style cuisine. Period.

This place is full of millennials who are in the business of waiting tables not to service tables but who think they deserve a tip for whatever service they choose to give. We were told by a fat waitress who looked like she got to eat for free that slices would be ready in 15 minutes and whole pizzas took 45 minutes. So we ordered a slice and a sandwich.  A couple got seated next to us but after 20 minutes of no service decided to go to the restaurant across the street. Then the waitress decides to come by saying, "Oh, you changed your mind?" We had to question why the order was taking so long after 35 minutes. We constantly had to flag this woman down to get refills. Then she was quick to drop off the check and say its seems you are in a hurry here is your check.  Then a minute later is asking if we need change. Why can't wait staff get it in there heads that it is, I will be right back with your change NOT will you be needing change? When they ask that i say yes i will be and then give them a lower or no tip at all.  Oh and the food was overpriced, charging extra on top of the already overprice sandwich for cheese $1.35 a slice and .80 for sweet peppers on a meatball sandwich priced at $7.45. Food presentation wasn't bad but did not taste as good as it looked.
Real good pizza!!!! Went to the one in the north suburbs since the wait for the one in the city was to long.. worth the drive.

Really disappointed with my experience today. Ordered ONE pizza for delivery at 12:45. After two calls to the restaurant, the pizza finally arrived at 3:30pm, cold and stale tasting. The saying "pizza is like sex, even when it's bad it's good" couldn't be less true here. All this wait for less than sub par pizza. Will not be ordering here again.
Simply the best Chicago style pizza; not even close. You will walk out here with a belly full of bliss, delight and complete satisfaction. Wing are great, too.
Good, fast service, except the pizza was not as good.Extra greasy. The crust and cheese were tasteless, but the pepperoni was alright.Two slices of good pizza are worth $10, but not this pizza

The best.As a south sider, to give that distinction to a north side joint, and for pan pizza is a big deal.  But it's the best in the City of Chicago.  You won't find anything close.  Lou Malnati's has a crust that can be compared, but it surely doesn't top Pequods, not by a long shot.  I literally go out of my way to stop in here, and we try to visit only once in a while to preserve the sense of novelty and make it a treat.

Move over Lou Malnati's and Giordano's! This is the best pizza in Chicago, hands down. Technically it is considered "pan pizza", not deep dish, but that makes it all the more delicious! Imagine the Noble Roman's pan pizza you loved as a child, pumped up on steroids. That is Pequod's. I am really picky when it comes to cheese/sauce/crust ratio on my pizza and many places like Giordano's are very heavy on the cheese and don't put enough sauce on the pie. Pequod's has the perfect ratio with a perfect amount of sauce so you don't have to order extra. The sausage is packed full of delicious, fennel(ly?) flavor, but the real show stopper here is the crust. It's deliciously chewy and caramelized around the edges. The only downside to eating here is that the wait is often incredibly long, but it's definitely worth it.

For my first ever visit to Chicago, I knew I had to try the deep dish pizza. As a NY native, I am a die hard fan of the thin crust. But when in Chicago...I had heard about the magnificence of Pequod's pies and came ready to eat (and wait). To our surprise, there were many seats available on a Sunday afternoon around 12:30pm! We got seated immediately and put in our order for a sausage pepperoni medium pie (6 slices for 3 people was more than enough).My first bite into the slice was the best. It was loaded with sauce & cheese and man, that deep bottom crust was so good. The only thing I wasn't blown away by was the caramelized outer crust that receives a lot of hype. I preferred eating the actual pie instead.I was impressed by myself that I was able to polish off 1.5 slices. Be careful trying to finish two; you may feel sick for a while. Otherwise, worth the visit and the future stomach aches!

Got take out, so I can't speak for inside of the restaurant. I had a friend visiting and he was on a mission to try different kinds of deep dish pizza. This place did not disappoint. The crust was sort of odd, more like bread, so if that's not your thing I wouldn't recommend their deep dish. We kept it pretty simple with giardiniera and sausage in one, with pepperoni and basil in the other. Very tasty!

If Pizza Snobs were celebrities I would be the Olsen Twins + the Kardashians.Pequod's is really, really good pizza.  I would also label it as a Chicago "must try" given its uniqueness.   For those new to Pequod's I think its important to point out:1) Their thick pizza is Pan, it is not Deep Dish.  Do not let anyone else tell you otherwise.  It is more of a Sicilian style thick crust pan.   2) The thin crust should be avoided.  It's not bad, it's just as good as others in the Chicago thin crust scene, and the crust is fairly thick and dull.  They don't apply the same burned cheese, mouth drooling, method that is used on the thick.3) The burnt cheese crust on the thick crust is awesome, and it just gives you that killer pizza "I am going to devour you" reaction aesthetically too.  Anyone who's had John's NYC will understand.4) Sausage and meat quality overall is fantastic.  Huge chunks, be prepared.

If you're looking for authentic Chicago deep dish style pizza then look no more.  Being a guy with eyes bigger than his stomach I believed the medium wouldn't cut it, boy was I wrong! After eating two huge slices my stomach couldn't budge anymore. It was either throw up in the restroom to make room for more or just settle for a to go box. The vomiting choice would be a win/lose. You win more room in your stomach, yet you lose the delicious beauty that you just scarfed down. Looks like you're in a picks huh? I ended up taking half to go. I stayed at the Hyatt Regency, and the weird thing is they didn't have a microwave in the room. So I was forced to keep it inside the mini fridge and eat cold pizza when my digestive system passed through all the cheese and bread from the two slices before. One downfall is this cold pizza was not satisfying. There is just too much bread that it just hardens up and doesn't taste like a normal cold slice of pizza. Other than that, I was more than satisfied with this place and I'm sure you wonderful Yelpers will be too!
It's the best deep dish the tourists don't know about it. I take all my visitors there.
If you don't like their deep-dish pizza then deep-dish just isn't your thing. Plan ahead before going, because the place gets packed.

Best deep dish in Chicago. If anyone is ever in from out of town this is my go to "Chicago pizza". The pizza does take 45 minutes at least to bake, so plan ahead. BUT you won't be disappointed with the delicious, cheesy, crispy, crust. Just writing this review is making me hungry for Pequod's

I thought it was quite good! Prepare to wait because it will be a while. From the moment we put our names in, to when we left it was about 2 1/2 hours. But that is to be expected from one of the best deep dish places in Chicago (so stop complaining, people). The only downside I thought was there was much more bread than cheese and toppings. But it was still tasty nevertheless! I highly recommend it.

I can only speak for myself here, but if I'm given the opportunity to order a final meal on death row, it's gonna be from Pequod's. Their pizza is the gold standard for me (both the abundant pepperoni thin crust AND the caramelized pan pizza), and the salad is also an absolute treat. My favorite now, forever and always.

Delicious crust on the outside, undercooked crust and veggies on the inside. I'm torn because the outside of the deep dish was so good (on the well done side with cornmeal), but the inside was meh. The yummy sauce was the tie-breaker, which is why Pequod's gets 4 stars instead of 3. That, and of the 3 Chicago style deep dish places I tried in my 3 day Chicago visit (yes, you read that correctly... I felt like a fatty for many moons after this visit).The service was kind of slow (it seemed like a busy night), but tvs with bad movies made up for it  :)

Probably one of my favorite pizzerias in Chicago.  Came here on a later afternoon on Sunday and got seated quickly (table for 2).  Ordered a draft bud light and the garlic cheesy bread to start.  The cheesy bread was delicious and toasty with a little burnt cheese on top with an amazing marinara dipping sauce.For the pizza (now we're talking) we ordered a small (shareable between 2) deep dish topped with mushrooms and sausage. It was delicious with the perfect amount of burnt crust on the edges (known for that buttery and cheesy crust).  I think next time I might just order the pizza with just extra mushrooms.

Maybe because I'm not a local and don't know what it means to have a Chicago pizza but this place was just okay for me. In one week I tried 3 pizza places and this was 3rd on my list.Pizza was fine, but didn't live up to the hype.
This isn't pizza, sorry Chicagoans.But for the casserole that this is, there's none better. Incredibly flavorful, delicious, perfectly cooked pie with great ingredients.

I was in Chicago. I needed to get pizza - the real stuff. And I had just come off one of those: "last night - late night ....had to order what I could, what was open.. last ditch effort unspeakable thin crusts that actually arrived to brick cold and bleh." Thats a review to come later - Save the better for first.I did take out and called ahead from the train - I had to do a quick stop and grab on our way to the airport or I couldn't squeeze it in. I walked like miles off the train for this pizza and I don't go far out of my way (which at the time it seems like I was walking forever) but it was WORTH IT, amazing and the people were rocking.1) I don't need to even comment first on the pizza - because let it speak for itself. I liked the atmosphere. Cute, on the corner - walked in - we were greeted right away with smiles and "What can we help you with!" Awesome! They were so gracious and kind - basically knew it was me! We were thirsty and they got us cups to go, accommodated us for our road walking journey with a speedy check out. I was so grateful. I wanted to stay!2) Pizza smelled so good in that box. Good price too although I just got myself a small thick crust cheese (basic) but it was piping hot and I couldn't wait to get my hands on it. Rich and saucy. I was in heaven. I couldn't eat it all and that says miles for an appetite like mine. I was fortunate enough to pass it off to someone in passing that probably needed it more than me and they got to share in Pequod's Yumminess too.Thanks for your "drive by" hospitality, delicious pizza, affordable pricing, cool venue and lifesaver when I needed my Chicago Style Pizza. I will be back!

This is my favorite pizza joint. I can't say anything bad about this place. Everything is sooo perfect!! I never eat sausage but this sausage pizza is soooooo amazing. Even if we waited 1hr for a table, and then another 1 1/2 hr for the food. It was all worth it. It used to be a 6 stars in my eyes, now it's only a 5. Hopefully they will go back to being a 6. :-)

The thin crust pizza was so, so good. I'm still thinking about it and it was two weeks ago when I had it for the first time. I didn't know the background of this spot. We just saw it was close to the movie theater nearby and it had some good reviews. We ordered a thin crust with pepperoni and ground beef. Pizza heaven on a platter I tell ya! Let me just say I came away impressed. Crust is a nice golden thin crust and not fake thin or soggy. Cheese and meat were fresh and quality. From the outside by all appearances it's very much a neighborhood dive bar/dining spot that one may not guess has excellent thin crust pizza. But this spot had waaaay better thin crust than many bigger chains or touristy stops I've been to that tout good pizza. If you're a big pizza fan you definitely have to try this place. I haven't tried the deep dish so I can't speak for deep but the thin crust was all that.

LOVE LOVE LOVE!! One of my favorite pizza places in the city!! I can't believe that other chains get more recognition because Pequod's is definitely one of the best!! Aside from the phenomenal pizza, the hot wings are also delicious!

You may want to rethink fat shaming in your restaurant. I was visiting a friend in Chicago recently and she brought me to Pequod's. Great pizza! But when I went to the bathroom there was a Bally's Fitness poster that said, "Yeah, maybe it does make your butt look big." Really? And in a Pizzeria? Also, there was nothing of the sort in the Men's restroom. Nice one Bally's! Nice on Pequod's!

When you enter the store, there is a large sign that essentially says that reservations aren't really reservations, but bump you up to front of waitlist when you arrive (I'm paraphrasing).Unfortunately, they don't do a good job of communicating this prior to getting there.  My party as well as three others (including a bachelor party that was forced to find other food) experienced this.    We received a text message the morning of the "reservation" asking us to confirm the time and amount of people, but nowhere in that message did it convey the variable nature of the time.Normally, not a problem, but if you have a larger party on a tighter schedule (ie bachelor party, or family with small kids), then waiting until 9:30 for an 8:00 PM "reservation" is less than ideal.    Would suggest management improve the pre-reservation communication, both on the website as well as the text messages.In terms of the food, overall quality was decent.  For apps, we ordered the pizza bread, assorted appetizer platter, and pequod salad.  Filled you up, but nothing to write home about in terms of taste.We ordered a thin crust cheese for the kids.   As a native New Yorker, I found the crust a little soggy, and the cheese a little excessive.  Sauce was excellent though.  Kids liked it, so that's all that matters.We also ordered a pan pizza with spinach/garlic as well as green pepper/onion.  It had a nice caramelized crust (highly addictive).  The dough was thick with a generous layer of sauce.  The veggies needed some extra salt, but overall taste was pretty good.  One medium slice was enough to fill me up, and I have a fairly big appetite.In summary, the pizza was pretty good (order the pan pizza over anything else), but I wouldn't wait 90 minutes for it....
This will be my shortest yelp review ever...BEST DEEP DISH IN CHICAGO - by a long shot.

My first visit to Pequod's was a pleasant one.  Very unique and delicious crust on the deep dish pizza.  The mushrooms were incredibly fresh and the sausage was wonderful.My only complaint, i had a side salad and their Italian dressing left something to be desired.Will be going back again!
Pequod's has amazing pizza. It might be the best in Chicago. Everyone should try this place at least once.

There are certain milestones when it comes to becoming a "real Chicagoan" and not just a glossy-eyed transplant from Cleveland. For me, changing the alliance of deep dish establishments was one of them. I had heard about Pequod's from people at work, but I stuck to Pizzeria Due and Giordono's as my go-to places. Until I tried the glorious caramelized buttered crust of Pequod's that is...then it was game over! Is the wait horrible most time? Yes. Is it kind of a pricy option? Yeah. But is it worth it? Heck yes!  If you're dining in, the restaurant is small, poorly lit, has horrible parking, and no where to wait...but the bar next door is pretty chill. But Pequod's delivery range is pretty big so it's easy to skip the hassle, stay in sweatpants, and have it dropped off right at your doorstep. This is THE deep dish to get in Chicago, end of the debate.
All i can say is that their pan pizza is great, but keep in mind that the bread will get absolutely soaked and soggy if you take it to go.

My favorite Chicago deep dish. Lou's is a close second, but something about the crust at Pequod's is just utterly delicious. I love the meaty meat toppings, abundance of both delicious cheese and sauce, and did I mention that crust‽ I don't have much else to say as I haven't eaten in the restaurant and I always make the same order, but had to share my love for Pequod's.
Chicago's best deep dish. Sausage and pepper medium was delicious. I recommend not getting the large as the caramelized crust on the large is slightly overdone
Pizza so delicious, you can overlook their awful pick up process.Seriously, it's that good.
It isn't technically Chicago style pizza, but it is my absolute favorite pizza in Chicago. Try the ground beef pizza, it's not the most traditional topping but on their pan style it really works.

We had eaten pizza at this restaurant twice. First time was excellent we thought it might be the best pizza ever. The second time at the restaurant was still pretty good. We had out of town company and even though it's expensive ordered Pequod's because we wanted our guest to try this delicious pizza. It was $60 not including the drivers tip for two large pizzas. One- one topping large and One- four topping large. We could have gotten two large pizza's elsewhere for  30-35 dollars less but we wanted the best so we paid the $60.I placed my order the day before. It arrived on time but it was barely warm. my husband met the guy and saw him take it out of the car and there were no bags around the box to keep it warm and for some reason sauce was smeared on the top of the bottom box. Their pizza is not good when it's not hot. We were very disappointed and not one of our guests said "wow this pizza is good". My husband and I agreed that we are done with Pequod's. I did call and tell the manager and he was nice enough. Said they have some problems to work out but unfortunately didn't offer a refund or anything just condolences. I think Pizza from almost anywhere else would have been better.  Also our receipt said 6:00 on it and we ordered it to arrive at 7:30 The manager said they set it up to start preparing it at 6:00. They tell you it takes 45 min to make their pizza but we have gotten it in 30 min. So my guess is they made it an hour early warmed it under a heat lamp (maybe) and didn't warm it in the car at all. It really tasted like it had been made the day before when I placed my order and was reheated and sent along. I don't think that's what they did but that is definitely the texture and taste it had. Although we will not return it is a good ( albeit pricey) pizza in house but don't waste your money on their take out. You can get a hot delicious pizza delivered to your home for a lot less money from somewhere else.

I've come to conclude that I am not a fan of Chicago style deep dish pizzas. So my rating remains neutral with Pequod's only because it was better than Giordano's pizza, but still failed to really impress me. I can't seem to figure out if you are to order, at most, 2 toppings or as many as you want. Because whatever we ordered with all those toppings (photo provided), it was not physically possible to pick up a slice and eat it with 1 hand, let alone 2 hands! I'm a grab-a-slice-and-go type of gal, and I couldn't figure out how to eat this except with a fork and knife. Which is fine. I can be a lady when needed. ;) But, again, it's just too overwhelming for my taste buds. And while others around us were devouring a whole entire pizza, we, sadly, couldn't get past a few bites. Honestly, it just seems like I'm just eating of bunch of baked/roasted pizza toppings and not an actual slice of pizza. There doesn't seem to be a balance between the dough, cheese, and toppings. Sad to say, I guess Chicago style deep dish pizzas and I are not meant to be~~

I had the pan pizza it was pretty good. All the appetizers I had were good but the chicken tenders were cheap horrible processed ones. Drinks are reasonably priced and good service. Overall good place to check out. Would of gave 4 stars if it wasn't for those disgusting chicken tenders.

Went on a weekday for lunch and there was no wait. The pizza was good and I can see why Chicagoans are big fans of Pequod's. I think I still like the butter crust of Lou Malnati's better but that might just mean I need to give Pequod's another visit soon.

This place has been hit or miss for me. The quality can really vary every time. The first time i went I wasn't a fan. The last time, it was absolutely delicious. So if you go once and don't like it, give it another try! Also better to go on off-peak hours when they're less busy.

I still can't figure out how to pronounce the name of the this place properly!! Even though about a dozen Chicagoans said it during my trip, I swear each one said it just a little different.I wish Yelp had 1/2 stars, as I think Pequod's deserves 3.5.  I'm rounding down and not up, because the other Chicago-style pizza place I tried during my Chicago foodie crawl (Lou Malnati's) was a solid 4 stars, and I think edged out Pequod's.After arriving into Chicago from Seattle at around 8pm on a Thursday night in mid-Sept, my foodie crawl weekend was just a subway ride and hotel refresh away!  My friend had already checked into our hotel earlier in the day and in short order, I was ready to get the party started too!  We had carefully crafted our itinerary knowing that we needed to hit up the late night places on Thursday night due to my late arrival.  After some small plates at Avec, our next stop was Pequod's and its late night hours (It was about 12:30am by the time we arrived).  Due to our jam-packed weekend of eatin', my friend and I shared a personal deep-dish pepperoni pizza only.  With a glass of red wine each.  The pizza took a while to come out (each one is made to order), but we were in no hurry-- after all, we were on vacation!!  It gave me some time to look around the small restaurant, (dive-bar chic was the ambiance) which totally reminded me of my college days.Once the pizza actually came out, it appeared to have a burnt crust.  We called over the waitress, who explained to us that it was the specialty of the house-- to put a layer of cheese along the outside of the crust, which burnt and caramelizes as it bakes.  Apparently some people would revolt if they stopped this practice!  For my friend and I, it was just a tad TOO burnt, so maybe we got one that didn't pass quality control... but I would say I wasn't a huge fan though the rest of the pizza was delicious.  For this reason L.M. was my favorite pizza place, though I can totally understand a late-night post-bar hankering for Pequod's-- in fact, in my early-to-mid 20s,  I could have seen myself being a fixture here!

This location has a sports bar feel and a bit small for groups and all the business they get. We had soup, salad, and their pan pizza. I chose the chicken tortilla soup which had no tortilla whatsoever but had a nice spicy flavor. The salad and house Italian dressing were good. The pizza was really good, not doughy as other pan or deep dish, and the sausage was huge and tasty. I liked the crust but my friend didn't. Even though I didn't finish my portion I was so stuffed that I didn't have room for dessert. The two waitresses helping us we're very nice.My experience was more like a 3.5 stars. We waited little over an hour on a Saturday night. Parking can be an issue. Their menu is small and simple which is not necessarily a bad thing. However, I was disappointed they didn't have their own specialty pizzas and that you cannot order any food before your seated on weekend evenings. So I would probably try it again on a weekday.
Yummiest deep dish in town. Period! Must go, must try.

They have great service and great tasting pizza. The crust comes out burnt so if you don't like burnt crust you should tell them ahead of time. When you get there they tell you the wait is 1hr to 1.5hr, but don't be shocked they usually get a table for you sooner than they say.

I've had Chicago pizza from many places and I feel like a pizza snob (Very high standards for pizza) in a way. I am not originally from Chicago (Kentucky originally) but lived there for many years and moved away. My favorite place was Petes on Western near Grace. My girlfriend, who is originally from New Hampshire, has never been to Chicago or had authentic Chicago pizza. Well, we decided to make a 7 hour trip from Kentucky to Chicago just for pizza. Absolutely no regrets at all. Service was great, food was fresh and hot, and staff was friendly and welcoming. I didn't expect anything else. Needless to say, we are fans of Pequod's and will be coming back. Next visit will be after we move. Such a great place and cannot express how happy we both will be moving back to Chicago. Thanks for a great night, Pequod's.

Hmmm... where do I start?Basically if I ask you what your favorite deep dish pizza is and you give me a different answer other than PEQUODS, I'll either assume you've never tried Pequods and/or you're from out of town... or that you have bad taste. Loads of cheese and sauce and they don't skimp out on toppings. THAT CARMELIZED CRUUUUUST. Their wait times are anywhere from an hour to more. But can you blame them?? It's deep dish pizza made by the Pizza Gods. I always bring my out of town guests to eat Pequods and I've never heard them say anything like "Hmmm, I've had better." or "It's just ok." Their eyes light up as they take that first bite and tell me things like "HOLY F*** THAT'S GOOD!" or "Don't talk to me for the next 30 minutes as I stuff my face with goodness." (Now that I think about it, I really hope they're all being sincere.)I can't remember if I've ever had bad service there, but I think personally the pizza itself trumps and cancels out anything negative, so 5 stars!

We are in such a huge hurry because we have to get our guest to the airport to catch a flight but we ate here before and frankly it is the BEST deep dish pizza in Chicago hands down!!!The carmelized crust is so freaking delicious and somehow the bottom of the pizza stays really crispy too which is rare for a deep dish!I say you should make every effort to visit this pizza place on your next possible opportunity!

Came here on a weekend getaway and we were prepared for the long wait so that didn't bother us! We got the wings as an appetizer while waiting for the pizza and they were DELICIOUS I totally recommend them. Since there are plenty reviews on here I will tell you ONE THING. Follow the advice of fellow yelpers and keep it simple when ordering... They pack the toppings on so no need to go crazy! My boyfriend didn't believe me when I told him yelp said to keep it to a couple toppings, he got a supreme style, and he wanted my plain pepperoni (but I didn't want to share)!

Taste is great but our crust was so burnt we couldn't even chew it. Deep dish crust is what we were looking forward to. We were starving so waiting another 40 minutes for a better pizza wasn't an option. Disappointed!

The pizza was great, very filling, and we were prepared for the wait based on tips here. Busy weekend night but we were given a booth & plenty of time - weren't rushed out the door. The only thing I found confusing is that the wait staff didn't have a set uniform - some were wearing black tshirts with the logo, others were wearing street clothes, and someone who seemed like a manager was wearing khakis. It made it seem like customers were rushing around, which I found confusing and distracting. The room got warm as the crowd grew.

Pequods is my favorite pizza place in Chicago so much so that I always bring out of town guest here first because you can easily get Lou Malnati's or Giordanos but noting compares to the caramelized crust and indulgence that is Pequods.For people that are uninitiated to Chicago pizza, I always say that you must try a couple of places and compare it to other Pan/Deep Dish places. You will be unsatisfied if you compare Pequods to other pizza you've had because of the difference in the category. Also, be careful reading any reads on Yelp -- always see where they're from! Most people giving low reviews to Pequods are out of towners and have not had Pequods or any deep dish pizza place more than once. If you compare it on it's merit to other Pizza, you'll be disappointed because there is no proper comparison (apples to oranges, both are fruit, but quite different.)  The one thing that Pequods has over it's closely competitor is the amazing crust. It's caramelized and burnt looking but it's toppings are no joke. Equipped with a fork and knife, it's a difficult proposition to eat more than a couple of slices. Generally, a large can feed a group of five or more!My only advice is to actually request more sauce. On lazy days, the pizza may come out too dry and a dry pizza is no good. More sauce gives it more of a hearty tomato taste that really balances out the superior Pequods crust.  Otherwise, pick your favorite toppings (Note: pepperoncini is not pepperonis, don't learn the hard way). Overall, the place is good for groups EXCEPT on any game day which will inflate your wait for both the pizza and a table. I wouldn't necessarily suggest bringing a family here either especially with younger kids or older adults because it has a very bar-y feel to the restaurant. Otherwise, it's a great place for friends (esp. those visiting from out of town to convert to Chicago pizza believers).
It's good. There are many things that could have been better - but the ingredients were good. Overall 7/10. Service was meh - lots of upselling.

Love this place! Try not to eat this kind of food often, but everytime is a meal well planned. Great staff everyone was thoughtful and carried the place Well. Gold i call it golden. This joint right here, Yummy for sure! Dont forget to ask Sally when you get there to Upgrade the special you will leave insatisfaction mode.

I'm not much of a deep dish pizza guy. Like Jon Stewart once said, I see it as more tomato soup in a bread bowl than an actual slice of pizza, but when in Rome (er, Chicago), why not indulge as the locals do?Pequod's was suggested by a friend who has awful tattoos, but a pretty solid taste in food and he didn't steer us wrong. A small deep dish was more than enough for two people and it was quite affordable as well (I believe it was somewhere in the neighborhood of $12). The best part were the burnt ends of the crust, and as someone who doesn't always end up eating the crust, this was a nice surprise at the end of the tomato saucy rainbow.The place itself is a bit of a dive and the perfect setting for a quick bite before a Cubs game. If I lived in town, chances are this would be my go to spot when craving a Chicago style pie (or "a f**king casserole" as Mr. Stewart calls it).

Golden Carmelized deep-dish pizza!  Need I say more?  The timely waitress returns to make sure food IS good.  The manager circles the tables to ensure the service is spot on.  The atmosphere is cool and clean, pepperoni is plentiful, slices are thick, and the Coca-Cola classic is bubbly.  No Kitchen Nightmares here.  Nicely done!

I think this might have been the most overrated place I visited in ChicagoI waited and hour and a half for a pizza that was burnt on the bottom and under-cooked in the middle. Also to make matters worse our server was petty much ignored us. She didn't refill our water or our drinks. If you are going to have sub-par food and least have good services.

I have been enjoying and recommending Pequod's Pizza ever since my first taste but my recent customer service experience set my opinion above and beyond what it was before (I apologize in advance, this will be detailed).My parents were visiting for dinner so I ordered a pizza for pick-up. When I arrived to get the order, the restaurant was swamped with at least 20 people waiting outside for their tables and even more waiting for their to go orders inside. A woman also picking up a pizza had an issue with her order but I didn't give it much thought until I brought my pizza home. After digging in, I realized there was a number of things wrong with the order and I sent a Facebook message to let the management know since something seemed to be happening in the kitchen causing orders to come out incorrect.I received a response that night offering to send a gift card, which wasn't at all necessary, but certainly appreciated. I received the gift card two days later and just went to enjoy a Friday night out for dinner. Upon arrival, we were told the wait was significant so they recommended we wait at a new bar two doors down where a receipt for our purchase there would give us a discount at Pequod's. The wait was much shorter than anticipated and we were able to place our order immediately once seated. The beer was exactly what we wanted on this steamy evening, the pizza was perfect and our Friday night was everything I wanted!Although the initial order was wrong when my parents were visiting, the customer service I received exceeded my expectations. The suggestion to wait at the bar next door, who's atmosphere was exactly what we wanted,  was everything we were looking for on a Friday night. I already was a loyal customer, but this experience was so much more than I ever expected that there's no doubt I'll go anywhere else for pizza, beer and Blackhawks games. Pequod's, thank you, for this experience. Businesses can take a note from you on how to ensure lifelong customers!

Absolutely love this place. I'm a huge Lou Malnatis fan and this is my new favorite. Now let's be clear, Pequods is not deep dish. It's Pan. So everyone comparing it to deep dish is way off! Anyways the crust is caramelized cheese and it's the best part! If your in the neighborhood check it out!!

I came to meet some friends here that live in Chicago, they suggested this place and wow did it live up to there words. I'm from nyc so we do flat pizza and the last time I was in Chicago I had giodanos and its was not what I thought. But lord this place the pizza was amazing! It just was to good and I loved it.

As much as I enjoy the Malnati's "Chicago" butter crusted  deep dish, the "za" at Pequod's is my favorite in Chicago. Thick cheesy deep dish pizza piled high with the toppings of your choice make this my favorite place for dine in pizza. The pizza is best eaten on site as it does not travel as well as Malnati's pizza likely secondary to the many vegetable toppings we had selected. We have eaten in several times and it was always excellent but took the same pizza to go and ate it thirty mins later and it had become fairly soggy so in other words it did not travel well. It frequently has a line/wait so be prepared especially on ball game days. In summary, if you want the best pizza and have the time to wait 15-45 mins to be seated then this is he place to go.
Great pizza, fun and lively atmosphere and good service. Got a table right away, but had to wait a bit for the pizza (but they tell you that right up front, so you are prepared).

This is our go to place for Chicago deep dish pizza. It is extremely hard to get into on the weekends. We have tried twice and been told an hour to an hour and half wait. Add in the wait to cook your pizza, and you're looking at 2-1/2 hour wait to get to fed. My advice if you intent on Pequods for a weekend night, don't go hungry! This last time we went on a Tuesday. A 10-15 minute wait was acceptable. We actually got seated in 5 minutes! Pizza was delicious as usual. Their sauce is great fresh, sweet tomatoes. The salad was disappointing. Lou Malanatis has better salads, they use romaine lettuce and their dressing is fresh, made in house. Our Cesar salad was made with leaf lettuce and the dressing was overly thick and salty. We ordered beer but unfortunately they were out of our preferred Allgash. Disappointing.

As a Chicagoan, I love all pizza. Thin, thick, stuffed, pan, deep dish, bagel bites, pizza for breakfast, cold pizza straight from the fridge. Pequod's does live up to the hype. I wouldn't say it's the best pizza, mostly because I don't have a favorite. I love all sorts of pizza, remember? Don't come here starving to death because you will most likely have to wait 15-30 minutes for a table. And then after you order a pan pizza, you'll have to wait another 20+ minutes. And for that reason, we ordered mozzarella sticks so we could have something to munch on. Nothing amazing with the mozzarella sticks and, unfortunately, ours were only slightly warm, which means the cheese was not ooey gooey.. boo. Anyway, the pan pizza is HEAVY. I would say a small 10" pan pizza is enough for two people if you don't want leftovers. In my opinion, the more toppings, the better! So we usually get pepperoni, sausage, green pepper, onion and mushroom. Their pan crust reminds me almost of thick focaccia bread doused in butter and cheese and baked until a nice, crispy outer crust is formed. It's definitely a delicious pizza straight out of the oven, however, I don't recommend take out since the pan pizza can get a bit soggy.

Best pizza in Chicago- it's as simple as that. Definitely expect a line, but definitely know that the wait will be well worth it in the end. If you're ordering delivery, it's gonna take a GRIP, but again- worth the wait.

I was in Chicago last weekend and on Sunday night me and my buddy wanted to gorge on some good Chicago Deep Dish pizza. I had tasted deep dish before, and knew what to expect.My buddy and I were bar hopping, and every bartender we spoke to told us to visit Pequod's Pizzeria for the best experience. As we were in downtown, we had to Uber it to this location, and it was less than a ten minute ride. It was late on Sunday night, so luckily for us the place was not totally packed although they only had a few tables where we could seat ourselves. Since we are vegetarians and were only two people, we ordered the ten inch, and added veggies (onions, tomatoes etc) to the basic pizza. The waitress told us it would take about 30 minutes to get ready, and we knew that going in. We asked her if we could go next door to Drinking Bird for a quick cocktail (Our bartender friends had also recommended we visit this bar). To our surprise, our waitress had no issues with us leaving the place for 30 minutes, and she did not ask us for a card or pre payment. That was awesome!Upon our arrival, our pizza was at our table and it looked delicious. Needless to say, it tasted amazing and the crust was so chewy and did not crumble.I cannot vouch for the meat laden pizzas, but ours was top notch.Will make it a point to visit this joint when I am in Chicago next.

Pequod's gets my vote for best Chicago deep dish.The cheese-to-sauce ratio is the golden ratio of pizza, and Pequod's is perfect. While some local deep dish places tend to go lighter on the sauce, Pequod's layers it on (but not excessively). Their sauce is full of seasonings and rich tomato flavor.As important is the crispy burnt cheese crust. Deep dish pizza tends to get a bit soggy, so the cheese crisped around the edges adds a nice crunch. And who doesn't love nearly-burnt cheese on their pizza?The individual (7") size is enough to satisfy two moderate appetites, but if you're hungry, you can probably polish off one solo. And with inexpensive delivery and no delivery minimum, Pequod's makes it easy to do so.

Hard to believe that I've been to Pequod's as much as I have and never bothered to write a review until now.  Let me start by saying I like this place so much that we held our rehearsal dinner here.  They have a back room upstairs that you can rent out that holds about 50 people, and I want to say they charged $40 per person for all you can eat and drink (including draft beer and I think house wine).  That would have been around May 2013, so not sure how pricing is now.I've had most if not all of the "famous" places around Chicago, and nothing will ever beat Pequod's for me.  I can't even tell you how many friends over the years I've turned on to this place.  Some are local and have since made it their staple place, and some are distant and now make this a priority stop when passing through Chicago.  I'll specifically never understand how anyone can like Lou Malnati's "wheel of sausage" pizza better than this.Regarding the pizza, the crust is amazing.  I know that it may not be "traditional" deep dish, but it's thick as hell and impossible to eat more than two slices, so it's deep dish to me.  When I eat the crust on most deep dish, it seems like I'm just eating a lot of cooked bread.  Pequod's caramelizes the crust, and most lovers would agree it's the highlight.  The sauce is also delicious, as well as the toppings.  My personal favorite pie is pepperoni, Canadian bacon, & giardiniera.  If you like spicy, the giardiniera is absolutely delicious (most of my non-Chicago friends don't even know that's a thing).Word to the wise, if you go at a time when most places are crowded, be prepared to wait a while to be seated, and to receive your food if you order deep dish (since it takes longer obviously).  This is Chicago after all, and any good restaurant is slammed
